content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												As a gun nut from Indiana I really wanted to love this game. I can't remember how I ended up getting it on Steam--I had it before I had a Steam account and I didn't like it then either. But I decided after reinstalling it that I would try playing it to see if I could get good at it.It was made in like 24 hours so it's perfectly excusable that I can't recommend it. But things like rendering shouldn't be a problem for most players of a game. I don't have much trouble with other, more complex games with textures and stuff that my computer actually has to load as it goes. Unless I reduce the resolution to like 560x480 or something ludicrously tiny like that, this game is completely unplayable because of the lag (a common complaint, it seems).Aside from that, this game is not intuitive in the slightest. It looks like I'm definitely not the only person who has had incredible amounts of trouble just figuring out how to load my handgun. Again, this is excusable because it was made in so little time. If you're a diehard fan of guns and roguelikes, have uncanny powers of patience and fantastic eyesight, maybe watch a trailer or something and see if you think you would like it. Personally, I would not pay anything for a sequel unless it was a fully-developed and crafted game.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2013
												This game is an interesting concept piece, but falls utterly flat on it's face. Everything about the game is in need of polish, from an awful UI (for such an extremely sparse UI as it is), to intentionally poor control layout, to the combination of these factors exacerbating its brutal difficulty. It's impressive how such a simple game can fail on so many levels.The game is brutal in it's difficulty. Not because the enemies can kill you with a single hit, or that they greatly outnumber you, or that you have very limited ammo, or that it's intentionally difficult to aim your weapon properly, or that some enemies appear to be able to absorb prodigious amounts of ammo for little to no good reason. No, the biggest difficulty creator is the fact that there is no rhyme or reason to the control layout beyond the normal movement and aiming and firing controls. Yes, the game is supposed to have a difficult mechanic of maintaining your weapon. But the button placements make no sense - they neither emulate the firearm that you are using, nor are they set up in a way that encourages a logical pattern. They're just generally clustered around the WASD keys like the developer just slapped them down whenever he thought of a new feature that guns have that he had yet to implement.The only hook into the plot (what little plot there appears be) is from audio tapes that have a poor voice over that you may or may not find near the beginning of your adventure. There is nothing that will make you feel like you have a need to complete the plot, other than any intrinsic desire you may still harbor for completing the game for the sake of completion alone.Also, a very special frustration that I managed to encounter is the fact that the game offers no way to reset one's controls to the defaults, but the UI that gives you control hints entirely works on having the default controls. So if you change your controls you'll either need to give up on using the tutorial UI, or find them online (at the time I write this I was incapable of finding them listed), or delete your registry keys from Windows so the game is forced into returning your defaults to you. The only people who should buy this game are the heedlessly masochistic and the curious game developers who want to explore the concept and how not to approach it. Even then, wait until it's on sale.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
-Quick Review-Receiver is a first person shooter that takes on the challenge of bringing in realistic gun mechanics, and an environment that looks like it was made by a student in his/her first few years using 3Ds Max. While not inherently "bad"... Receiver isn't a game that will be enjoyed or appreciated by most people; that is why I'm giving it the down vote, to be honest I don't recommend or recommend-against playing this game, I simply didn't find it enjoyable.-Detailed breakdown review-Story:  You there! collect all the tapes! "who me? Why do I want to do that?" That's what I want to ask, but I'm not given that luxury. I collected only a couple tapes before getting tired of being murdered by the turrets 10+ times. Presumably you are collecting these tapes to uncover a mystery within the game and to understand what's going on inside the game.Game Play: First thing you do: Press ? on your keyboard so you can see what to doSecond thing you do: go through an acurete and realistic weapon arming proccessthird thing you do: run around and collect stuff on the floorfourth thing you do: run into your first enemy and get yourself killedGoal: To collect 11 tapesThe highlight for this game are the gun handling mechanics, you don't simply press "R" to reload, depending on the weapon you're using you need to press a button to change the cartage and then press a button to load a new one.For the revolver, you actually need to open the revolver, take out the old bullets, and put in new ones. While very interesting, and highly realistic, the game is not very easy to learn and will require learning new tricks if you want to actually survive the game play.I took down several of the auto turrets, there seem to be two kinds: Flying, and stationary. Both of them are really annoying if they spot you. If you get seen, you have a second to dodge around the corner. My instincts to shoot back usually ended up getting me killed. Achievements: No achievements (thankfully), unless you want to make them for yourself, I think collecting 11 tapes would be quite the accomplishment. Price:  This game just ended up in my steam game library, so free is free, but the price is $4.99 on the steam page. Probably not worth it for most people. Conclusion: I realize this game was made for the "7-day FPS challenge" which is why the graphics and the environment is very basic. But I just didn't really enjoy the game play, if there was more story, or just something to keep me interested I'd probably enjoy it more.This game would appeal to people who want to see what a game would be like with more realistic gun mechanics, however after playing it, I see why these types of mechanics aren't implemented in traditional shooters; because it breaks up the action within the game.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												I played this a lot considering how not-good it is. It's refreshingly low-stimulus. You engage at your own pace* taking short bursts of high risk. "High risk" can be as mundane as turning a corner. If you don't see the telltale spotlights, robots shoot you and you die instantly. Situational awareness is sacrosanct and there are no non-diegetic distractions. It manages to be tense, and then routine, which causes laziness and then death. The high lethality, immobile enemies, and detailed gun manipulation emphasize readiness. To get ready, there's lots to do. There's nothing like being ready to go with a robot around the corner, magazines topped off, safety off, ironsights up, and dying because you forgot to chamber a round. The game does suspense very well.You start completely over when you die. You collect random pickups for your random gun around randomly placed enemies in random structures**. There are "plot" tapes to collect but you won't realistically collect them all ever. Some are blank. It's neat how nakedly cultlike they are. Like a real-life cult, not videogame-standard delusional idiots. Mystical ideas have materialist labels. The speaker in the tapes is a gun-and-apocalypse obsessed cult leader. He says they're magical superpower-granting tapes. You have to listen to all of them a ridiculous number of times (it's meta, you will hear the same ones over and over.) Your gun holster and pouch and loose ammo is standard kit. It's almost what the Branch Davidians would sound like if they did their propaganda mail-order.Ultimately though, it's not very good. It's kind of ugly. It's badly optimized, and lags when generating a new area. There's hardly any content. The lighting is obviously wrong in places. Some of the procedural areas don't "line up" and connect right. One map area has stairs with an invisible ledge you have to jump over. If you jump on a bed your head clips through the ceiling. The environment can clip through your inventory. It's possible to get physically stuck where it's impossible to get out or die. There are a ton of tapes and sometimes the random number generator is just unfair. The game has a lot of problems. It's an extremely unrefined version of a neat idea***, so I wouldn't recommend it to most people. It's only five bucks and I'm not most people, so it worked out for me.*I died at spawn once because a robot spawned in an adjacent area in line of sight.**Technically procedurally random but who cares.***Because it literally is, it took a week to make.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												A game meant for guns nuts above all else. This is essentially a pistol simulator, i.e. there is a key for every step of reloading a pistol, like taking the magazine out or putting it back in. It was a cool concept at first, but it wore out fast. What is a gun sim without fun things to shoot at? The only things to shoot are turrets and flying drones.  It is actually more beneficial to avoid most of the enemies than to actually shoot at them with your gun. This "game" gives off a deeper tactical impression with its focus on gun realism, only for it to boil down to a silly minigame where you avoid turrets and drones whilst simultaneously collecting nonsensical tape recordings.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												WOW... major dissapointment. I really wanted to like this game, I really did, but there is a major problem with it. This game is sooooooo poorly optimized it is nearly unplayable. According to the store page, my PC not only met the Minimum requirements, but the Recommended requrements (barely but still) yet the game had UNBEARABLE framerate and mouse lag. I  mean it takes almost 2 seconds for the gun to move after you move the mouse. Sure, what's 2 seconds? Well in a game where you have enemies that are flying quickly, turrets that can kill you almost immediately after spotting you and limited ammo to hit small targets on previously stated enemies... yeah the mouse lag can really be a problem. It wouldn't bother me if the requirements of my PC aren't powerful enough, but I have read the requirements and they match (so don't blame my crappy Computer that [supposedly] meets the requirements). Now onto the actual game... there isn't much. The game is very simple. Collect all the Cassette Tapes around the level, while killing off all enemies and trying to survive. The main feature is the realistic gun unloading/reloading mechanics. Everytime you need to reload or whatever, you need to manually pull back slide, take out magazine, store in inventory, take new magazine out of inventory, load new magazine, unlock slide, and pull back hammer before being able to fire your gun. Each step has its own corresponding key to hit and it overall is annoying. It loses its novelty very quickly and just makes reloading a chore. It also makes it impossible in a firefight. Also each of the three different weapons has different reloading sequences... great.Also levels are randomly generated after death. So once you die, cassete location, enemy location and type, bullet count, flashlight batterey life, and gun type all change. This gives the challenge and overall is annoying since enemies (who instakill I should add) can be right around any corner. Also bullets are in random spots so good luck finding them when you have ran out and are now running from your life against flying guys in a hallway that has a turret around the corner at the end of it. What should happen is instead of the levels randomize after death, have a randomize button so you can know the layout and actually finish a level.Overall, the game has a cool idea but the poor optimization and annoying instakill enemies with tiny weakpoints ruin a game that could have had some really tense atmosphere.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												While the gun handling is really good, everything else is iffy to bad. The story in the tapes you collect ingame is mildly interesting, but not great. There's very little music, and it's nothing special. The level is really basic, boring, and overly minimalistic. Visuals are generally kinda ugly, without much style too. There's only two types of enemies, and while the idea of hitting them in specific locations is a cool idea, it's really tough in practice. The turrets aren't too hard to hit (there's a bit of a challenge, but not too much) or in some cases just to avoid, but the flying drones are nearly impossible to hit in the critical spots, and can require more than one hit, despite them flying extremely erratically. Combat can be frustrating, and not in a way that made me feel skilled for dispatching an enemy, so much as glad I wasn't hit myself. After almost two hours of trying to enjoy this game, I realized my hope was futile. The idea and core gunplay of a game is there, but nothing else of substance. Oh! I almost forgot the worst offence! It's buggy and laggy to high hell! I thought it might have just been my so-so laptop I had played it on, but numerous other reviewers had the same issues. 3.5/10 could have been something cool (and lag free) if the devs spent more time on it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2013
THIS GAME SCORES [0 1 | *2* 3] = ~62% (50%-75%)It's not a good game, but that's not what you should buy it for. It's about the gun handling. Once you have gotten the hang of it and played a while, you'll want mechanics like these in other games, too, and I'm not aware if there are any so far. I do not feel like these mechanics must be the focus of a game (And they indeed aren't in this game, they'll only seem like that to a beginner for whom they'll be the main obstacle.), they could just be a nice element of realism, but the game would of course have to be balanced accordingly.At first, I had real trouble getting the hang of the gun mechanics, even though there's on-screen help in the game (that you can toggle). But then I did this, and it helped a lot:In the game's launcher, I edited the keyboard configuration to a set of keys that I could easily remember and that made logical sense to me. This plus the key function texts in the configuration window made it easy for me to start handling the guns in a routine way. Downside: The in-game help does not adapt to the changed keyboard config. :(So, the gun handling and mechanics are fun. What about the game itself? Well, it has very limited gameplay. You sneak through a (procedurally assembled, so somewhat different play-through each time) facility, trying to obtain bullets, magazines, guns, a flashlight, and a few audio tapes. You'll encounter flying turrets that you have to fend off, and there are floor-mounted turrets. It's interesting that both consist of various parts, and shooting those has varying effect depending on what you hit.Is it fun? Yes, for a few hours, and it's mostly interesting because of the gun mechanics. It's not a full game, rather a prototype. Worth the purchase? Definitely when discounted, but €5 isn't all that much, either.The FOV is not low but can not[pcgamingwiki.com] be changed!

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												One Sentence Summary - If you like pressing 15 buttons to shoot a gun, buy this game... otherwise, buy something else...--REVIEW--I simply cannot say that I recommend this game. It seems that this game was more of a tech demo than anything. Other than the "Tron" sounding background music, this game really doesn't provide any emotional connection with the player. The game simply starts... there is no story provided, other than the players having some sort of idea that they are running along some rooftops looking for cassette tapes. I assume these tapes give some sort of minimalistic story. I get the point that this was made for some 7-day FPS challenge, but they could have at least given the player some sort of story or motivation to find these tapes. The graphics are incredibly minimalistic, yet it runs poorly on my laptop, even on the "fastest" setting. I get much better performance playing something like Dragon Age or FInal Fantasy 13 than I would on this game. When I turned the resolution down to the lowest setting (like 600x800 or so), I got decent performance. You might as well do this, because you won't lose any graphical details... because there are none to lose. I believe this to be either a hardware compatability problem or simply not programmed well to run efficiently.---PROS---+Minimalistic/Non-existent story (if you like that sort of thing)+Tron music+Very "realistic" process of having to load and reload a gun.---CONS----Minimalistic/Non-existent story-No Tron motorcycles or discs-You have to press way too many buttons to load a gun. There is no tutorial or simple explanation other than pressing the "?" button for help, and blindly pressing the buttons until your gun is ready to shoot.-Graphics are very minimalistic (AKA- Didn't have time to add detail)-The game runs extremely poor on a dual core laptop with 8GB ram.-For the average game player, I think the gun loading process is extremely cumbersome... At least make a tutorial or arrange the buttons in a streamlined order.---CONCLUSION---If you like randomly generated worlds in games with no story, as well as tron music and hard to load guns, this is the game for you. For the rest of us, we'll be better off playing something else.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Receiver is a First Person Shooter about guns. Like, really about guns. The main attraction of this game is how it handles gunplay so realistically. Rather than have you automatically reload, you have to manually do each step to reload. If you miss up, there's just more time for flying sentries or turrets to get you. The point of the game is to traverse a randomly generated maze of bleak colors to find cassette tapes that provide background to the universe.The game's atmosphere is wonderfully dark and creepy. It does a great job of making you feel alone, and the dark colors combined with the low-quality models and textures create a sense of dread and otherness that makes you really feel like you're out of your element, running through a maze you have no map of that's filled with enemies that are more location-savvy than you.The gameplay is fun and rewarding. When you first start, you're probably gonna be really slow at handling your gun. You'll die a lot, and you'll forget certain steps, completely halting any progress in loading a new magazine into your weapon, typically under enemy fire. You won't have much ammo, and will have to conserve your bullets, though eventually you will run out right before entering a room full of enemies. As you get better at the game, you'll be able to load your gun faster and be more precise with your shots, wasting less ammo. This game does a good job of making you feel like you are progressing at the game because it is solely skill-based.I'd buy it.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												I love this game. For being made in a single week, and only having ONE content update, this game manages to create so much tension, and feeling, and amazing, it could put some big-name games to shame. And the mechanics are super fun to learn and use. Randomized level generation keeps things interesting, and the one hit death keeps a certain tension in the air that keeps you on your toes. The only two issues I have are as follows; no sprinting, and performance. No sprinting simply because if you happen to be crossing a large room or bridge with nothing around, navigation can be tedious. The performance thing is only an issue if you play full-screened. Just keep it in a window, with the appropriate level of detail, and you should be able to run it just fine.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Receiver is a fun "gun simulator". The gun mechanics are very in depth. You can't reload just by tapping "R". You have to eject the magazine, load each bullet into the magazine individually, then put the magazine back in. Each of these actions has its own key. While somewhat confusing at first, you can eventually memorize the keystrokes for reloading and other gun mechanics.The objective of the game is simply to collect 11 cassette tapes, unlocking somewhat vague pieces of the game's story, and not getting killed by the two types of enemies. Enemies will kill you in one hit. If you die, you have to start completely over. It is far from an easy game.There are also 3 types of guns, but I downloaded a mod that adds even more. For a 5 dollar game, it kept me entertained for quite a while, and I'd say it's definitely worth a try.

												Receiver is a fun "gun simulator". The gun mechanics are very in depth. You can't reload just by tapping "R". You have to eject the magazine, load each bullet into the magazine individually, then put the magazine back in. Each of these actions has its own key. While somewhat confusing at first, you can eventually memorize the keystrokes for reloading and other gun mechanics.The objective of the game is simply to collect 11 cassette tapes, unlocking somewhat vague pieces of the game's story, and not getting killed by the two types of enemies. Enemies will kill you in one hit. If you die, you have to start completely over. It is far from an easy game.There are also 3 types of guns, but I downloaded a mod that adds even more. For a 5 dollar game, it kept me entertained for quite a while, and I'd say it's definitely worth a try.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Before you chew me out for only playing an hour and a half of this game first let me tell you about it. This game is great. The idea is fantastic and the sense of survival it goes for is achieved. Does it look like it could have been made in Google SketchUp? YES (at least on my computer it does). But it goes surprisingly deep for what it is. You spawn in a random part of what appears to be a huge house, or apartment bulidings, or neither I'm really not sure. You are then given one of three handguns, a Glock, a revolver, and a Colt 1911. This is where the game get's really interesting. The controls focus around the gun. There is a key set to open the reciever, a key set to take out the magazine, a key set to pull the hammer back. Everything you would actually do with a gun, and magazine for that matter, there's a key for it in this game. To me that is fantastic. It's new to me, and I tend to doubt there have been many if any games that follow that same idea. The second interesting point of this game are the audiotapes you pick up. They give a wonderful backstory to the game, telling you why you are there, and hinting at something sinister. In that way, it's like the Matrix, only voiced by Microsoft Sam. If you see this game for 50%, heck 33% off or more buy it. You will not regret it. This game get's my 7/10. The idea is great, but I wish the game was more replayable.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Some people will take this game very boring and uninteresting and some people will find this game very very fun. It's a quite unique game in my opinion.First thing: the way you handle the gun is very realistic, so the button layout is very different than normal games, especially when you reload. You have to press each button for certain actions; for example, with a revolver, you must 1) open the chamber 2) drop all the empty cartridges (some may get stuck sometimes, so you gotta shake em/hit the key repeatedly) 3) reload each bullets 4) close the chamber. <<so there are 4 different buttons to press to reload as for other games, reload is just 'r'. There are three different types of guns: Glock, Colt 1191, and S&W revolver. They all have different ways to reload, but the same action = same keys. You will feel SOOOOOOOOO achieved if you get used to reloading well that you can reload smoothly and fast without even thinking.There are only two types of enemies in this game: automatic sentry gun & flying taser robot, which is kinda scary when you actually face them because they **cking fly at you like a tsunami. They have limited sight (so sneak when you're out of their sight and ambush? I guess. That's not a very good word for this kind of situation but I suck at English so... Yeah..) but they if they detect you, good night man (unless you have an Asian reflexes on mice or consol that you can hit certain part of robot when it's flying the **ck at you). And damaging certain parts will either break (different parts) or kill the machine.Anyways, the goal of this game is to find 11 recorded tapes and I think it's game over then. HOWEVER! I bet not a person among 1000 players can finish this game as fast as they thought it would end. As you can see, I played 10.4 hours of this game and still wasn't able to finish the game and I consider myself not THAT bad of a FPS shooter... I'M ASIAN FOR GOD'S SAKE!Uhh.... I wanna explain more but I gotta go to sleep so.... maybe if someone asks to write more about this game I'll write it in Korean and English both detailed. Oh and also, are there any games out there like this? Because I'd love to see this kind of game actually developed well. I mean... This game was made in less than a week so great respect for that. Gnight it's late is Asia.-Devil-

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
Warning:This is not a complete game, consider this a tech demo since this game was done in a week!Now that we got that out of the way, onto the game.Receiver is a first person shooter rogue-like. Everytime you spawn, you get a random weapon with a random inventory on a randomly generated world.The objective is simple, obtain 11 tapes around the map and you win. But it's not that easy. There are enemies scattered around the world and it is your choice to either bypass them or shoot your way through. Remember, your health is a 1 shot kill. So you only get 1 chance.The main core of the gameplay in this game is the guns. Unlike normal shooters, youl have to input various keys to perform actions in your guns. Reloading can take 4 keys to press. The ballistics include bullet drop and ricochet. While the gun mechanics are pretty realistic, the enemies have a pretty estratigic way to deal with them apart from just shooting them.While there are only 2 types of enemies, they are enough to make you pull your hair out. Enemies are pretty much sentries and drones. And they must function somehow. The strategy to eliminate enemies is to shoot vital parts. For example, you can shoot the sensor and they won't spot you anymore. Il leave the rest for you to find out the other vital parts. If you so desire to get the game of course.But lets review the features of this game.FeaturesDetailed simulations of a Colt 1911 pistol, S&W Model 10 "Victory" revolver, and Glock 17 with full-auto modWhile partially true, the guns do have detailed models and ways to operate them. But they mostly include only the important bits of the gun for the gameplay.Taser robots and machine gun turrets with physically-based damage modelsAs said above before the features. This is true.Ballistic modeling of ricochets and bullet dropAgain, as said above, this is true. Nothing else to had.11 audio tapes to prepare you to defend yourself against the inevitable Mindkill eventThe tapes are the objective of the game, these tapes explain the world you live in, the guns and how to use them, the machines and how they work etc. They also include parts of the story. I find this a very interesting way to have a tutorial. But it's not a very good way to deliver one. The audio tapes are random, so the chances of you getting a tape explaining how the enemies work, can take sometime.Become literate in how guns actually operateI can confirm this since I shot the floor, the bullet ricochet and still killed me. Don't shoot the floor kids.While the game can be fun and frustrating at times, it delivers quite an experience no other game can achieve.I belive it took me 9 hours to finally complete the game once. Now for the moment of truth. Buy or not to buy?For 5 bucks, i'd say go for it. While the game is simple with complex mechanics, as a rogue-like I belive it offers alot of replayability.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Been playing this game here and there for a while now. This game is pretty nice in a lot of concepts. For example, how you control your gun. There are 3 basic weapons; The M1911 Colt, the Glock 18, and a .357 Revolver (I think it is a .357) and all three have their own way of control. The Colt and Glock have the same controls except that hitting V forthe Colt will put on the Safety while the Glock makes it either go Semi or Automatic. I like the Revolver and how you can spin the chamber as much as you want with the mouse wheel. Or you can spin it before you place it back. There is a lot of stuff about the game that makes it a good game. On the other hand, I do go through a little bit of some issues here and there. For example, I get random FPS drops when going through different areas on the map, but it goes away half a second later. And I am currently having Lighting FX issues (Probably my side). Besides that, this game is definitely worth it. Especially with the recent gun additions to the game.9/10

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												For a game made in a week, it's pretty great. It's inherently satisfying to manually reload your weapon as quickly as you can, once you have a grasp on the mechanics. It's tense and fun when you hear a drone around a corner, look out for its camera light, and time it just right to shoot and disable it unscathed. There's some nice use of adaptive music, a scarcity of ammunition forcing you to make every shot count, and some terrifying flying drones to escape from.However, being made in a short amount of time, in Unity, and using randomly generated environments, I've run into framerate issues, repetitive environments, graphical whoopsies, and situations with no chance of success. As well, the objective of collecting tapes involves listening to a monotone voice drone exposition that is often heard over and over again after respawning. You can fully mute the voice volume in the settings, at least.It's worth the $5 pricetag, but I was happy to pick it up on sale if you catch my drift.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Receiver is one of those rare games that feels entirely new and fresh.While it is your standard survival-adventure shooter in terms of action, it is so much more than that. Receiver is one of those rare games that actually makes you work to succeed. You have to memorize the steps to get your gun working or you will die quickly and repeatedly, you have to learn your enemy's weak spots, you have to learn how to safely enter a room or hallway. Receiver is near impossible difficulty, but I always find myself picking it back up.It's not a game about completion, but rather a game about mechanics. The guns feel good, the game has occasionaly jarring (but generally good) progression.You'd be daft to not get this game when it's on sale.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
Warning:This is not a complete game, consider this a tech demo since this game was done in a week!Now that we got that out of the way, onto the game.Receiver is a first person shooter rogue-like. Everytime you spawn, you get a random weapon with a random inventory on a randomly generated world.The objective is simple, obtain 11 tapes around the map and you win. But it's not that easy. There are enemies scattered around the world and it is your choice to either bypass them or shoot your way through. Remember, your health is a 1 shot kill. So you only get 1 chance.The main core of the gameplay in this game is the guns. Unlike normal shooters, youl have to input various keys to perform actions in your guns. Reloading can take 4 keys to press. The ballistics include bullet drop and ricochet. While the gun mechanics are pretty realistic, the enemies have a pretty estratigic way to deal with them apart from just shooting them.While there are only 2 types of enemies, they are enough to make you pull your hair out. Enemies are pretty much sentries and drones. And they must function somehow. The strategy to eliminate enemies is to shoot vital parts. For example, you can shoot the sensor and they won't spot you anymore. Il leave the rest for you to find out the other vital parts. If you so desire to get the game of course.But lets review the features of this game.FeaturesDetailed simulations of a Colt 1911 pistol, S&W Model 10 "Victory" revolver, and Glock 17 with full-auto modWhile partially true, the guns do have detailed models and ways to operate them. But they mostly include only the important bits of the gun for the gameplay.Taser robots and machine gun turrets with physically-based damage modelsAs said above before the features. This is true.Ballistic modeling of ricochets and bullet dropAgain, as said above, this is true. Nothing else to had.11 audio tapes to prepare you to defend yourself against the inevitable Mindkill eventThe tapes are the objective of the game, these tapes explain the world you live in, the guns and how to use them, the machines and how they work etc. They also include parts of the story. I find this a very interesting way to have a tutorial. But it's not a very good way to deliver one. The audio tapes are random, so the chances of you getting a tape explaining how the enemies work, can take sometime.Become literate in how guns actually operateI can confirm this since I shot the floor, the bullet ricochet and still killed me. Don't shoot the floor kids.While the game can be fun and frustrating at times, it delivers quite an experience no other game can achieve.I belive it took me 9 hours to finally complete the game once. Now for the moment of truth. Buy or not to buy?For 5 bucks, i'd say go for it. While the game is simple with complex mechanics, as a rogue-like I belive it offers alot of replayability.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												This game is, well, strange,I'm not sure what the story is, but all I know is that you are a in somekind of dream machine and you need to find tapes to unvail the truthGraphics/Art style- I like the art style in this game. It's very blocky, but this game shows that you don't need graphics to have a good game. This also reminds me of those retro days where the first 3D games were all blocky and sometimes pixely. Although I like the are style, there are some bugs that I found that make giant block spawn in my way and completely blocks of the only entrance to the last tape. 8/10 for retro score, 5/10 for score against games with good graphics. (the 5/10 score will not be put into the final score)Gameplay- For gameplay I would say that it's ok. It's actually quite spooky if you get randomly attacked by one of the flying turrets, but searching for the tapes is quite boring most of the time. Sure, you might say that you will run into a lot of turrets, but I spawned in once with no turrets.  7.8/10Price- 5.49 is the price in Canada, but is it worth it? YES! For the price, this game is great, and you will receive lots for the five bucks, besides IT IS 5 FREAKIN DOLLARS!!!!! 9.3/10Final verdict- If you like Indie games, then sure go ahead! This games will be a great buy, but if you don't like waiting and looking for things, than you might want to pass on this. Final Score: 83/100

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												I lied in my last review, or at least looking back now i was, because i started playing more games and got a better idea of what a video game should be and this is not it. Now one could make the argument that "it is better than cod" while it might be better in the long run, it is just a sloppy game that had a very short time window. If it had more time then i could see this game being more playable but i seem to be going on nothing so i'll start the real review now. First off, guns are few to none and tiny little robots that want to turn your chest cavity into swiss cheese are every where, you may spawn with a gun or a flashlight or simply nothing. Finding a gun isn't very easy because you die pretty fast because you have as much bullet resistance as President Lincoln and when you finally get a gun, the magazine is shorter than a Japanese midget.  Objectives are not marked, there is no way to find your way around and there are no checkpoints. If you find these complaints stupid and like COD, then you have COD on your mind, because listing all the FPS's with those 3 things would take longer than i care for. This game does need navigations though, because every time you die the world gets randomized leaving you lost. Marked objectives are a must have because the only objective is to collect these little VHS tapes or what the hell ever, and they are small as a Chinese elf and some times blend into the enviroment.  Overall this game is just not worth playing, not only is it filled to the brim with bugs it is only fun for 20 minuets AND you die from 5 feet falls, i sh!t you not. Maybe if they made a Receiver 2 and put more behind it than "OH LOOK WE HAVE RANDOM GENERATED WORLD N' ROBOTS N' GUNS" then i would consider playing it. 3/10

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Been playing this game here and there for a while now. This game is pretty nice in a lot of concepts. For example, how you control your gun. There are 3 basic weapons; The M1911 Colt, the Glock 18, and a .357 Revolver (I think it is a .357) and all three have their own way of control. The Colt and Glock have the same controls except that hitting V forthe Colt will put on the Safety while the Glock makes it either go Semi or Automatic. I like the Revolver and how you can spin the chamber as much as you want with the mouse wheel. Or you can spin it before you place it back. There is a lot of stuff about the game that makes it a good game. On the other hand, I do go through a little bit of some issues here and there. For example, I get random FPS drops when going through different areas on the map, but it goes away half a second later. And I am currently having Lighting FX issues (Probably my side). Besides that, this game is definitely worth it. Especially with the recent gun additions to the game.9/10

												how to actually reload a gun and manage ammo simulator. This game is purely based on getting a good seed where you actually have a clips worth of ammo when you spawn, and that you aren't immediately swarmed by 2 turrets and 3 flying drones in the first room you walk into. Haven't beaten it yet. Graphics are crap, and everything feels awkward. But that's kind of why I love it too. It's kind of the addiction you get from playing qwop, where you barely feel in control, but with a sense of reward from collecting those tapes and those tense moments in each new room where you have no idea if a turret is going to come out of nowhere and shoot your♥♥♥♥♥♥off. It may be a bit sloppy, but every respawn feels fresh and it could be a while until you give up. A great game to pick up on a sale of 50% or so.tl;dr: it's a short and sweet game, meant to be picked up at about 2$. You get what you pay for, but odds are you'll enjoy it while it lasts.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Receiver is a very interesting little experiment that bases its gameplay around the mechanic that you have to manually reload your weapon like a puzzle, essentially a on the fly FPS puzzel game.It doesn't take too long to figure out how to properly reload everything and very soon you will be reloading faster than ever, so in the end it becomes a interesting little survival game to keep you distracted.I honestly wish this game would continue to be updated because there is a huge realm of possibilities to add in terms of weapons that could be used. Like shotguns, crossbows, bolt action rifles, all of these things would bring fantastic variety to this game, adding onto the list of different weapons you need to remember how to reload in different ways.But alas, it remains as it is, with only 3 weapons to use and toy with. Although the product itself is good, it's a shame when you imagine all that it could of had.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												For a game made in a week, it's pretty great. It's inherently satisfying to manually reload your weapon as quickly as you can, once you have a grasp on the mechanics. It's tense and fun when you hear a drone around a corner, look out for its camera light, and time it just right to shoot and disable it unscathed. There's some nice use of adaptive music, a scarcity of ammunition forcing you to make every shot count, and some terrifying flying drones to escape from.However, being made in a short amount of time, in Unity, and using randomly generated environments, I've run into framerate issues, repetitive environments, graphical whoopsies, and situations with no chance of success. As well, the objective of collecting tapes involves listening to a monotone voice drone exposition that is often heard over and over again after respawning. You can fully mute the voice volume in the settings, at least.It's worth the $5 pricetag, but I was happy to pick it up on sale if you catch my drift.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Receiver is one of those rare games that feels entirely new and fresh.While it is your standard survival-adventure shooter in terms of action, it is so much more than that. Receiver is one of those rare games that actually makes you work to succeed. You have to memorize the steps to get your gun working or you will die quickly and repeatedly, you have to learn your enemy's weak spots, you have to learn how to safely enter a room or hallway. Receiver is near impossible difficulty, but I always find myself picking it back up.It's not a game about completion, but rather a game about mechanics. The guns feel good, the game has occasionaly jarring (but generally good) progression.You'd be daft to not get this game when it's on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Some people will take this game very boring and uninteresting and some people will find this game very very fun. It's a quite unique game in my opinion.First thing: the way you handle the gun is very realistic, so the button layout is very different than normal games, especially when you reload. You have to press each button for certain actions; for example, with a revolver, you must 1) open the chamber 2) drop all the empty cartridges (some may get stuck sometimes, so you gotta shake em/hit the key repeatedly) 3) reload each bullets 4) close the chamber. <<so there are 4 different buttons to press to reload as for other games, reload is just 'r'. There are three different types of guns: Glock, Colt 1191, and S&W revolver. They all have different ways to reload, but the same action = same keys. You will feel SOOOOOOOOO achieved if you get used to reloading well that you can reload smoothly and fast without even thinking.There are only two types of enemies in this game: automatic sentry gun & flying taser robot, which is kinda scary when you actually face them because they **cking fly at you like a tsunami. They have limited sight (so sneak when you're out of their sight and ambush? I guess. That's not a very good word for this kind of situation but I suck at English so... Yeah..) but they if they detect you, good night man (unless you have an Asian reflexes on mice or consol that you can hit certain part of robot when it's flying the **ck at you). And damaging certain parts will either break (different parts) or kill the machine.Anyways, the goal of this game is to find 11 recorded tapes and I think it's game over then. HOWEVER! I bet not a person among 1000 players can finish this game as fast as they thought it would end. As you can see, I played 10.4 hours of this game and still wasn't able to finish the game and I consider myself not THAT bad of a FPS shooter... I'M ASIAN FOR GOD'S SAKE!Uhh.... I wanna explain more but I gotta go to sleep so.... maybe if someone asks to write more about this game I'll write it in Korean and English both detailed. Oh and also, are there any games out there like this? Because I'd love to see this kind of game actually developed well. I mean... This game was made in less than a week so great respect for that. Gnight it's late is Asia.-Devil-

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2013
												Once I got past that horrible voice from the Gemini Rue commentary trying his hardest to sound like Werner Herzog, Receiver revealed itself to be the most exciting and rewarding shooter I've ever played. The moment you realize you've been reloading and operating your M1911A from reflex memory, you feel giddy. And then you become just careless enough to get caught in a simple drone trap that you would've spotted if you weren't in your own head. Unlike most 5-30 minute games out there, this one has replay value because it's actually fun and you do more than just walk around. No, you don't learn about the magical power of love and ponder humanism. You shoot stuff.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												The gun reloading mechanics are neat, but the iron sighting to aim is terrible making the game not fun to actually play. If you were to aim an actual gun, you would keep the gun lined up to the target with your vision. When you aim in this game, however, moving the mouse moves the gun around a certain amount before turning the character. This means aiming is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥and very unrealistic to actual gun aiming. I also had to massively reduce my mouse speed in order to actually aim, though it was still hard to aim as the gun jumps around for every pixel you would have moved with your mouse.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Reciever is worth looking at if only for the way it handles its pistols in a much more mechanical, realistic fashion than most other FPS's. Unfortunately, that's the only thing it has going for it. It's an interesting concept that is trapped in a half-baked, Slendermanish shell. Random weapon loadout, random level design, search for the mcguffin objectives (with embarassing voice work), and frustrating enemies that have locational damage models that mean that it's pretty much random if your shots do any good. Basically, the game is designed as youtube scarecam fodder, with all that entails. As a proof of concept, it does a magnifcent job in demonstrating more immersive gun mechanics. As a game, it gets old really fast.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												For such a simplistic game, it should take only about 1.5-1.7 GHz to play this. But no. It lags like crazy even if you have a medium PC. Think about this. Skyrim, the massive open-world, plays fine on my 1.7 GHz laptop at 30fps to 60fps at medium settings. This game, plays about 10fps constantly. I can tell they didn't care about this game because the graphics are terrible and they didn't even take time to optimize it. There is some stuff good about it like the combat and use of atmosphere to give you an alone feeling and other stuff but I'd say that it isn't really worth the £4 that it sells for. Maybe £1. Overall, I believe its a like it or hate it game.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2013
												I guess if youre from Texas shooting deer with your AK every morning or something this "game" (experiment actually) might not be of much interest. For anybody else this could offer an interesting insight into what gun use entails besides point and click and pressing r.It would really be interesting to see those mechanics implemented in a "proper" FPS. Heck it could practically breathe new life in the Zombie/Survial Horror subgenre.Beware, once one gets the hang of the controls and can switch mags,♥♥♥♥♥♥hammers, put bullets in and out of magazines and all that jazz its great fun but unfortunately there isnt much game to put that to use in. Theres 2 enemy types one of which is annoying to deal with due to sluggish movement, the style and graphics look nice (i was abit reminded of Mirrors Edge) but the performance is comically bad for what basically amounts to rendering gouraud shaded objects and some lights.If you ever played some realismo fps and wished the gun handling to be more complex, give this a spin and wonder what could be.

Posted: March 16, 2015
												Some quality gaming. The most high quality gaming I've had the pleasure to game in quite some time. To game on this game you have to press a lot of buttons, gaming that only a real gamer can game in a game. I went into this game expecting a quick gaming session, but in all my years of gaming I have never misjudged a game's gaming potential so badly. The game itself is simple to game, you are a simple gamer and the game is to find 11 game tapes for the game. You game with a gun and you find ammo, and if you game hard enough you might collect all 11 tapes. I have not gamed hard enough for such a game as this, and I have disgraced my gamer family. But I haven't heard of anybody gaming hard enough to give this game the business (game business, of course), so perhaps I will be allowed back into my game family. Quality game for any gamer to game when they feel like a casual game or a serious game this game can go either way. I'd rate this game pretty well but, being a simple gamer, I am compelled to meme.10/10 would game again

												a really good idea but a really rushed idea as well.  many people probably don't know that this game was made in 7 days.  the maps have holes in it, respawn logic makes no sense, and due to its rushed out style, theres a very severe lack of textures to everything.  what i ment by this is that everything is jsut a solid color with a shadowmap on it in its most simplist modeled forum.reciever will not be a gam that you would look at for entertainment but rather a demonstration of what not to do when making a videogame, don't rush it.

												This game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, the Randomness of the game makes it so terrible, you can turn a corner to find a sentry gun that makes no noise and will fire at you instantly. I spawn in dark areas that lead to straight to a drop that kills you, this is made even worse by the fact that your flash light has a very small distance it will show you. I kept spawning right infront of enemies or I would round the first corner only to see a sentry or a flying blade machine that would instantly kill me. The flying machines travel way to fast and sparaticaly to even aim at till they kill you. To be honest this game is very good for being made in 7 days, just it should not have been sold on steam for $5, because overall it's terrible from a gameplay standpoint.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2013
												Let's get it straight from the get-go. This game won't win awards for graphics, plot or sound design even if I think the guns sound meaty enough. This game is basically a quicky roguelike involving a gun and I strongly suggest tapping the ? button followed by holding it down while handling different things so you can quickly learn how to take your gun apart and reload it. That right there is why you're playing this game. You're vulnerable, the gun is barely a comfort and you're constantly worried you're going to take one step too far and find yourself dead and starting over. The three guns all feel a bit different and funny enough, just like real life, I can't stand the Glock. Points for involving a revolver and the 1911 though. It's five bucks, if you're a fan of shooters or if you actually shoot, this game is at least worth a look at some point. I wouldn't mind seeing a proper game made of this concept. I like it.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												This game is pretty damn awesome. It's a basic, relatively simple game that doesn't look amazing, but what's actually there is great. Each level is procedurally generated so the map is never the same, you always have randomized ammo/equipment, and one bullet from a turret or shock from a flying drone will kill you. It makes piecing together the 2spooky story that's told across 11 tapes randomly placed on the map very difficult, but wonderfully tense. And of course, there's the game's real star - three guns that operate the same way actual firearms do. There's no crosshair, no ammo counter, and your mags don't magically refill themselves - assuming you have more than one, anyway. Doing a brass check and topping off magazines with loose rounds are actually things you'll find yourself doing in this game, as are other gun-specific actions like releasing the slide, dropping empty brass from a revolver, and spinning a cylinder to a loaded chamber, all of which require multiple button presses to accomplish. Sometimes, you'll even find it necessary to holster your weapon to complete an action such as filling a magazine, or pull the weapon down from the "aimed" position into a low ready to sprint away from danger. It's not the prettiest or most action-packed game out there, but Receiver is the closest a game has ever come to recreating the sensation of using an actual firearm. Very, very much worth the $5 purchase price.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												For a game that was created in a single week, it runs exceptionally well and is quite addictive.  This game, unlike other FPS's, take the approuch of being as real as possible: Every single thing you do with the gun is another step for you to take.  Unloading a clip?  Reloading?  Safty?  All of those need to be done one at a time.  Although this may seem risky, this game does it to a whole new level and makes it interesting.  Mechanics are a bit awkward to get a handle of at first, but after about a half hour of play-time, you begin to get the hang of it, gaining some progress in the game.  I can almost memorize all the buttons required for reloading.Enemies are nothing special, though: they basically boil down to stationary turrets and flying robot helicopers from SpyGear with tazers that go *zap*.  Nothing unique, but far from being easy.This game does a good job of making it a challange without making it either laughably easy or insanly hard.  At first, the game is difficult, but then you get a hang of things and it begins to get easier.  It's well paced.Randomly generated areas also help the game's overall success.This game is fantastic for what it is.  The best part is that I didn't even need to pay for it: They announced that if you pre-order their other game, "Overgrowth" (which is an excellent game as well; I highly recomend it) you get a free copy of "Reciever" as a thank you gift.Thanks, Wolfire games!  ~Ohyoupokedme

												I thought about writing a positive review for this game, but then I realized I was going off half-cocked. Now, I'm not exactly gun-shy, but I think I really shot myself in the foot after shelling out 5 dollars for this.Now, let me put a bead on the issue--This game had me chewing the rag for a bit. It didn't exactly feel as if the developers had kept their powder dry.  I fell for the "gun-lover niche" lock, stock, and barrel. I actually enjoyed the game for a bit--but then I realized the experience was just a flash in the pan. The game wasn't exactly loaded for bear--its arsenal wasn't the most varied. I'm not just shooting blanks here--there are only 3 guns in this game that absolutely focuses on firearm-realism. I know the developers made this in 7 days, but it feels like they went off on a hair-trigger.TL;DR meme game get it on sale for 3.99 or less.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This is a brilliant game, I have to say. It only has three guns, and it only has two types of enemies, and it isn't full random generation (Like games such as Starbound), more on that later. However, the game is so much fine. If you think you can come into this and hit R to reload and see your ammo in the bottomright corner, then NO. This game is much more than that. You have to move every individual piece of the gun by either holding or tapping a button, and if you get ONE thing wrong, by the time you go around a corner and attempt to fire the gun and you realise a drone is flying towards you with its taser on the ready, you're basically dead unless you're me.The game features permanent death. If you die, that's it, all of it is erased, but if you get hit by something ONCE, and that includes your own rebounded bullets (Or bullets you accidentally shot yourself in the foot with), you die. The game generates the world via procedural generation. It basically takes a load of giant buildings, adds some custom things to that giant building (Bullets, enemies, etc.) and then connects it to another giant building. All of the giant buildings have three floors. The game then spawns you in with a random weapon, a random amount of magazines, a random amount of loose ammunition, a random amount of ammunition in magazines, and a random state of your weapon, also it decides whether or not you will spawn with a flashlight and decides whether or not there is an enemy looking at you just as you spawn in to challenge you. You then tuck into a corner and get your weapon all ready. If you find yourself ejecting live rounds out of the side of the gun and then pulling the magazine out of the gun and dropping it off a building or similar, you should press the ? key to bring up a context-sensitive help menu. What this means is that it will show all the things you can do, however things recommended to get your weapon into recommended operation (As in, full auto off, ready to fire, safety off etc.) will be coloured white, and things not recommended will be a dull grey.The enemies in the game consist of only two types. There are actually four types, however two of them were cut for time restriction reasons (Or I assume), as this game was made in a 7 day FPS challenge. The two enemies in the game are the immobile machinegun turrets, which will now be called turrets, which spin around slowly with a blue light on them, and when they see you, the blue light turns yellow, it makes a beeping sound, it tracks you, and very shortly after the light turns red (to indicate "THREAT DETECTED") and then it opens fire. You have to either sneak past it or kill it if you want to advance in that direction most of the time, and the way you kill it is not just "fire until it has no more HP", you actually have to aim and shoot at something and if you shoot, for example, the camera, it will not be able to track you, or shoot at the magazine and it will not be able to chamber any more rounds, but that still means it can still fire one bullet, and I've heard that it tends to trick you, as in hold fire for a few moments to indicate you probably shot out the firing control, and then fire that one bullet straight into you, though no confirmation. There is a small chance for you to be able to hit a nonvital area on an enemy and shut it down, however most of the time absolutely NOTHING will occur when you do this.There is also these shock drones, which most of the community tends to call them taser bots, or just drones (However don't get into that habit - there is another type of drone that isn't in the game but may be in the game sometime in the future), however I will just be calling them shock drones from now on. They fly around, they find you, they then have the same lights on them as the turret, but then they engage, they rush at you, they try to taser you. These are flying death if you don't deal with them shortly after they spot you, they will even hide above or to the side of doorways and wait for you to come out so it has a tactical advantage, they are VERY intelligent but they have no fear of you, keep that in mind.The two unreleased types of enemies are: The mobile turret, which is basically a turret on wheels, it looks like it'd go quite slowly and would obviously have the inability to go up stairs, but it'd be terrifying. The other type is a drone with (what I assume is) a gun on it, which would be one of the most deadly enemies to ever exist if I think I know how they'd work, however they probably wouldn't fire nearly as fast as an immobile turret (Nor would the mobile turret) or be as accurate, the turrets are deadly accurate and will one shot kill you if you aren't moving, and even if you are moving and not running they still have a high chance of shooting you in one shot.I've told you alot of the game mechanics, you should get a basic idea of it, however I haven't told you about the story or the objective.The objective of the game relates to the story, therefor I have to give you a basic understanding of the story for you to fully understand the objective. I will try not to go into detail at all, the story will probably be much more advanced than I describe. Here we go: The story is basically an unknown force called "the threat" wants to neutralise humanity because of their ability to gain an "awake" status. There are two realities. Reality B (which is basically actual life) and reality A (Which is basically dreaming). An "awake" status is where you can exist fully in both realities, if so much as a single human achieves an Awake status, they would see beyond the horizon. The threat weakens the resistance to The Mindkill through media. Once they were sufficiently weak, The Threat striked and initiated the Mindkill (I forgot what it actually does, listen to the tapes in the game to figure it all out (I'm not good enough to listen to them all yet!)). The Receivers are able to resist the Mindkill, and as such have to be neutralised specially, so they are placed in this universe (The universe where Receiver takes place). There are supplies aswell as casette tapes around the area (Placed by I don't know! I haven't listened to the tapes in a long time). To achieve an awake status, Receivers must listen to the tapes repeatedly. The maximum amount of tapes required to achieve an Awake status is around 100, however the minimum is 11. There are 11 tapes. One of them is a Cleartape, which, to most people has nothing on it, however if you are close to the Awake status, you will hear things on it.To stop the Receivers from reaching the Awake status, the Threat "Dreams" killdrones (the enemies) to the Receivers' location, which then activate. Alot of this is not implemented such as the cleartape things or the repeatedly listening to tapes, but it will give you an idea of the storyline. You have to collect the 11 tapes before being killed.The game has mod support, and it has a quite popular mod which adds a firing range aswell as a few new weapons. There is something you should do with this mod to get you started, it's an exercise I created: Basically, you go to the firing range, activate the weapon selection, and then choose the first weapon in the list, and then hold L to reset your game. You then need to put the weapon into full operation order without making a single wrong action, this does not include pressing a button that does nothing, however it includes things like dropping the magazine. You have to repeatedly do this correctly and discharge the weapon a few times without making a single true mistake and as fast as possible, you have to set the amount of times you want to do a weapon, I recommend 3 to start out with, however after a while move it up to 6. If you perform one error, you need to hold L, reset your score, and then try again.Once you get to the limit, you then select the next weapon in the list- I'm out of space.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2013
												Created by a team of 4 in a week for a FPS game design challenge, Receiver revolves around realistic gun mechanics in a (very) randomly generated world. Despite being an FPS game, the gameplay focuses more on actually controlling and preparing your firearm and stealth rather than on modern "realistic" cover shooting concepts. Reloading magazines manually,  emptying revolver chambers, and juggling your inventory are actually all very enjoyable, even more so when you manage to learn the controls. The randomization is very strong, starting you off with one of three random handguns, a random amount of ammo, and occasionally a mag light. Room objects, enemies, pickups, and lighting all are randomized, making you want to explore. However, the randomization also causes issues; one game I spawned right next to a taser drone with 3 bullets. Overall, I think this is worth picking up just to experience it, especially with the low asking price.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Fascinating concept for a game. You actually have to manually operate your weapon. The game is procedurally generated with regards to the placement of enemies, ammunition, and the objective collectibles. Your success can depend on what weapons, equipment and however much ammo you start with, all of which are random. You can start with anything from a .44 with a dozen rounds, or a 9mm with three measley bullets. The gunplay is satisfying and tactile, and the game is arranged such that you won't need to do the dozen things involved with operating a gun in a hurry. The pace is slow, and you have as much time as you like to get ready. It's possible to get up a list of keyboard commands on screen to help you know what to press and what does what. In all, a great concept, very well designed. Hopefully we see more like this in the future, with more scenarios perhaps, or some sort of multiplayer deathmatch. Very good price for a couple of hours fun. Definitely pick it up, especially if you catch it on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 30, 2013
												Receiver challenges players to traverse a randomly generated landscape of buildings in search of 11 cassette tapes.  This is no simple task, with flying and stationary turrets primed and ready, permanent death in one bullet, and realistic weapons simulation, death awaits every corner.  You must learn how to manipulate every part of a weapon from pulling back the slide, ejecting the mag, and manually refilling cartridges.  What's usually simple, is suddenly a challenge in memory and nerves as you fumble to reload with death at your back.  Welcome to the real world of guns.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2013
												Very interesting game. Moderately difficult gun mechanics. Interesting grim and cyberpunkish ambiance despite it's low-budget nature. Rogue-like, enemies hitting you means instant-death, hence very challenging, I couldn't beat the game yet. Things often go smoothly for some while, where knowing the buttons halfway through is enough to know. More often than not you'll find yourself facing multiple enemies at once - hovering shock drones that hunt you down, and stationary sentry turrets - with only a few bullets left in your magazine, choosing to either fight or run. This can put you under some stress and make you panic. It's where the wheat is probably seperated from the chaff in this game. As it would work in real-life I assume when you not know your gun inside out.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Interesting? Yes.  Fun? No.  Great idea.  Ultimately poor execution.If it were free, I'd have recommended it. On sale for $1-2, meh-aybe.  Probably not worth $5.I realize this isn't some triple-A, and I wasn't expecting one.  I don't really regret my $2 spent (on sale).  But if I were to go back I'd probably've skipped this one.  I didn't find the game fun, and often found it frustrating.The Good: I really enjoyed the fresh take on the FPS, and appreciate the realism.  I hope some of it is incorporated into full-fledged games.  Though only a few pistols, they contain more character than most game's entire arsenals.The Bad: Gotta hack the Linux version a little if you don't wanna play on a 5" screen.  I have a high-end rig, yet performance was somehow a problem.  Its particularly frustrating when you're playing at a crawl-pace to avoid dying (you die so easily and frequently that you're forced to), only for the game to stall for a second when you finally encounter a robot and that's that, game over.  I was frequently placed in dark portions of the level w/o a flashlight to start w/ (even when you find a flashlight, it only illuminates ~10 feet or so).  Even after maxing brightness on my monitor I was annoyed w/ how hard it was to see in the darkness.Oh yeah, and don't expect anything from the 'story', as it consists of tapes w/ an annoyingly borish voice droning on about something I didn't care about (something about how 'dangerously addictive media' had destroyed the world).In conclusion, it really is mildly interesting, and I appreciate what the devs did.  Its just more of an experiment/demonstration than a game.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Receiver is a very intresting game. Although the world lacks color, and dispite it's limitations, it's got plenty of action. The game has an unusual feature that you don't see in most FPS's. There's no push-button reloading. You literally have to do each step manually to load your weapon, be it a 1911, a Glock, or a good old fasioned revolver. Dispite how much work it sounds to be, it really adds to the experince.It also includes a small help feature, which gives suggestions to new players on what the need to do to prep the gun.This game is well worth the money you spend on it.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Very interesting concept for a video game. The player is in control of ever piece of the gun and needs to quickly prepare to fire in case of attack by the many turrets hidden around the randomly generated map's corners. It is a very difficult game that will truly make you think of when is the best time to fire your weapon. A good 20-30 minutes of fun.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2013
												Receiver is a really interesting simulation game that should be played by alot of people. In reciever you play as gun wielding spy who needs to find 11 tapes so he can find out how to fight wawes of mind tech robots. In the game theres three guns a revolver, and a glock. Theres also two types of enemies A mind tech turret and a mind tech drone. The game is really fun and the gun mechanics really spice up the gameplay. The first time you reaload your gun you feel the biggest satisfaction. Now about the gameplay. The gameplay is really tight and works fluid. But the difficulty  is insanely difficult. You will want to use cheats that were impilmated in the game. Overall a really fun gun game so go ahead and check it out. I give a 8/10

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												I don't remember how much I spent on this game, but if it was even 10 cents, I want my dime back.I'm all for a challenge, I'm all for dungeon diving through hoards of♥♥♥♥♥♥to find random lore that may or may not be important. I actually liked the system they implemented in having realistic magazines and weapon mechanics, but for all that, ♥♥♥♥ THIS game.Your character holds and shoots, whatever weapon you have, in a way that makes Call of Duty sniping, without steadying your scope, look like a good idea. This, being your only real method of survival against the flying enemies pretty much ensures that if there is more than one near you at any given time, you will die. Even if you're keen enough to deduce a way around enemies to get where you want to go, your character takes 6 foot falls like a toddler and you will probably end up dieing due to your apparent brittle bone disease.TLDR: Good ideas, poor execution.2/10

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												More of a tech demo than a game. But the basic gameplay elements, controls, are rarely if never before seen. I have not encountered a game that makes you actually manipulate a firearm in the ways this game makes you. You are forced to load a magazine manually, load the mag into the gun, turn the safety off, rack the slide, then you can commence the shooting. Which is unweildy and hard to remember during high stress situations just like with real guns. Its a shame the gameplay is crap and it runs so poorly on my machine. Framerate bogs down for no reason for me and the enemys that fly are often going to kill you out of nowhere. Its all randomly generated, but more often than not those flying ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s will be in a ridiculous spot that its either easy to shoot them or you are dead before you could even know you were being attacked.That said these elements need to be taken and put into a survival horror game. Chance the controls for firearm manipulation to the mouse maybe or not, this game needs to be made.But unless you really like to see diffrent games and this "game" is on sale than don't buy it. Its not worth the price they have asked for it because its very very basic to the point of being a demo of gameplay for a much larger game. A larger game that dousn't exist.

												I guess this game was made for people who like two things: FPS games and pushing random buttons on the keyboard. This game's main mechanic is having a pistol that you literally need to press a different key to do each action with. Unlike conventional FPSs, reloading is not simply pressing the "R" key, there's a full sequence. I will give the creator of the game the benefit of the doubt and say they were trying to go for interesting mechanics, but all they really succeeded in was creating a frustrating game that's pretty much just annoying to play.The game is essentially rogue-like, so even if you end up progressing in the strange plot at all, one small misstep, and you (which I assume is made of paper mache) die and need to restart immediately. Interesting concept, terrible execution. Honestly, I'm not sure if there is a way to execute said concept WELL, but as it stands, I cannot really say much in favor of this game. Maybe if the devs actually spend more than a week on this game and actually polished it, I could recommend it (Not even making this up, the game was made in a week). But it's buggy. It's basic. The core gimmick mechanic is annoying at best. I got it for free and would not say that anyone should buy this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Never played such a fun fps like this before.What makes it fun unlike other shooting games is that it shows realism in the gun, and you have to use the gun manualy, and properly.This game will force you to understand your gun, and how to use it properly and realisticly.One thing I love about fps's such as these is that the developers are open to new and experimental idea's, such as this game, I encourage more people to make games like this.This is my favourite type of fps games out of all the rest, it has potential and also has a more thrilling adventure to the weapons itself, unlike other fps games now days.I just love having the dismay of worring if my weapon was reloaded correctly, or what condition the weapon mode was under, or especially at the times when my gun was nearly out of bullets and I forgot to check and got myself KIA for it.This game will punish you for any miscalculation or incorrect use of your weapon, and I absolutely adore that!―NOW WOULD I RECOMMEND THIS?―Heck yes, I will most definitely, absolutely, positively recommend this game to all fans of guns, fps and simulation.You wanted a realistic shooter/ simulator, well this game is for you!

Posted: March 23, 2015
												Definite "or nah" for this game. You move around a boring empty building with a single gun and 1 clip. The controls suck and aren't intuitive and refilling the clip with bullets picked up aren't explained and there's no control in the help section for it, meaning you get 1 clip. Better controls, and more things to do besides walking around shining a flashlight and seeing 3 robot turrets would have helped. It is cool they are putting more focus on actually operating a gun, but more time could have been taken to optimize it and improve the controls and make it easier, more fun, and fluid. They just chose to make it more obtrusive to increase difficulty and learning curve, when not necessary. Theres just nothing to do besides inspect a chamber and load/unload a clip, with only 1 gun. 4/10.
