												A challenging FPS that doesn't lose any charm or fun once you get into the swing of things. Easily one of the more challenging games I've played, as it's quite unforgiving in both mechanics (learning the layout and order to load, reload, check ammunition, etc.) and gameplay (drones and turrets that track you via sensors and dish out instant kill shots). Though it's rather straightforward in terms of story, the randominzed gameplay alone was enough to get me hooked, and the complex gun mechanics only sweetened the deal.Be warned; you will die. Posted: October 2, 2013
												1)  This game was made in 7 days.  Yes, 7.2)  It isn't pretty, but it works, and it works well.3)  It features realistic gun handling skills interms of loading and reloading.4)  An entirely randomized layout makes for (argueably) infinite replayability.5) If you get shot, you die.  No HP, no medkits, no healing potions.  D. E. D. Dead.   Receiver is based almost entirely upon realistic gun handling.  There is a distinct lack of surface textures, but you can't expect the Mona Lisa in a game that was made in such a short time.  I picked this game up on sale for about $2.50, but I would recommend buying it even at its original price.  Receiver takes a bit of getting used to, and the story line certainly isn't unique, but it is quite fun either way.  A perfet playthrough can see the game completed in about 30-40 minutes or so.  But it took me almost three hours of overall gameplay to reach that point.  For under a dollar per hour of enjoyment, I'm happy.

Posted: September 29, 2015
												This game is ridiculously addictive. Simple gameplay (Takes a bit to learn the reload) But it is extremely satisfying, I found myself checking my magazines and the chamber of my Glock Or 1911 several times before entering into a new room. My absolute favorite part is sometimes you will spawn and immediately  have an flying Killbot after you. Madly Pulling the trigger on your revolver only to hear the devestating *click click* of two empty cylinders, but you keep pulling the trigger to find that the third chamber was loaded, you hit the bot its thrown off but its still coming after you, you squeeze again.*Click* Empty. The bot is charging you, you pull one last time to find the last chamber had a final round hidden. Bang you hear the impact and the bot goes down. Every time that happens my heart is racing and i need to step back from my keyboard to calm myself down! This is such a simple and cheap game. But it is designed well, and feels thought out. A+++

Posted: September 28, 2014
												This is not a game for everyone so wether someone recommended this game or not is almost entirely based on their taste in games and as such introduce some bias. That being said I will now impart some of my bias upon you. Reciever is an interseting game to say the least: no fancy graphics, minimal to no story, and a difficulty on a level of reality unobtainable by another game in this genre. Where Reciever truely shines is its delivery of narative through gameplay. There are a few (11 to be exacy) tapes throughout the game that have recordings on them that help explain the basic premise (the  goal of the game being to collect all 11), but the entirety of the feel and the lessons this game imparts (as any game worth its salts has at least some knowledge to impart) are based in its mechanics. This game takes guns very seriously: they kill. You take one bullet in this game and you die. Not to mention, as many comments will tell you, they ain't easy to operate (E, ~, 2, 3, ~, Z, R, F to reload?). Which leads to the conveince of theme. This game is hard. It is almost pointless to expect to win with any sense of ease; which is exactly what the narritive delivers. Without spoiling too much, you can essentially die endlessly in this game. A never ending cycle of death, failure and pain. Sounds like a message to me (not to mention the recordings speaking of a dystopian society). This coupled with the game's core mechanics being gun manipulation means that the narritive is almost entirely non-verbal, which is fantastic. Again, I do not reccommend this game to everyone (it is rather artsy and only made in a week), but is excellent for what it is, and I hope we can all learn something about guns from something other than Battlefield, CoD, Halo, etc where they're just tools. I wish you a good day, and thanks for listening to my ramblings on :) Cheers!

Posted: January 31, 2015
												Ya know, there is a reason why free to play games exist.In Receiver, we follow the story of a silent protagonist who's name is apparently "Reciever", or as i like to call him "The Ghost of Guns Past" (its just a floating gun no hand no nothing). This game was made for the 7-Day FPS challenge in which, as the name implies, is a callenge to game makers to create a First Person Shooter (FPS) in 7 days. And you know, its actually pretty good! So why am i giving this a low score? The game is just annoying to play to be honest. I know what you're thinking, "Hey Vandal, if you say this game is pretty good then why did you just say its annoying? You just completely contradidcted to what you just said!", well allow me to explain reader. What i meant by that was that its a good PROTOTYPE. This is what the game feels like, plays like, and looks like. This game honestly should be a Free to Play tech demo. Not a game worth $5! The game is also procedurly generated. Which means that, the level will be randomized with each playthrough. Now on other games that sounds good (i.e. Being Minecraft, Starbound, Binding of Isaac) but on this game it just fails to impress. Sometimes I spawn with a flashlight, the gun, about 4 fully stocked mags, and with the cassete tape in one room (You have to collect these things for god knows why). And sometimes i spawn with absolutly nothing! The other thing that makes this game bad is its TERRIBLE narrorator. In video games narrorators are supposed to retell past events, present events (Trine series), or just quirky narration (The Stanly Parable). The narrator in this game sounds like he was forced to do this. As in he sounds he hasnt gotten any sleep in months and is bored out of their mind on the brink of insanity. Pros:-Looping music is catchy-Guns are replicated good-Guns sounds are almost realCons:-Game suffers from confusing gameplay-Virtually no story if any-Horrible narrator-Not worth the $5-EXTREMELY CONFUSING controls-Bland textures-Crap hit detectionThe Final Verdict: 4/10I am being greatly generous with that rating. The game is not the worst game on pc (in my opinion at least) but it's definitely up there. I cant say anything else worth mentioning other than the fact that i can go on and on ranting about how the game shouldve been free instead of it costing money. I refuse to recommend this game to players unless you're a gun nut. If thats the case disregard this review and go buy - HANG ON NO DONT BUY IT! If you are a gun enthusiast, the look up "World Of Guns: Gun Dissasembly". At least there you can go crazy on numerous guns. The game would be better if it was still being in development by the dev team. In conclusion the game is not good. I know I dont have the right to say that since i only played it for about 6 mins. the uninstalled it. But in my opinion, unless the team makes a better version of the game, this game will forever be the worst game i have ever played.Even "Dead Bits" was a better game than this.-Evan

Posted: February 16, 2015
												Verdict: 8/10 (50/10 when considering how quickly it was created from scratch)Pros: Novel concept, challenging gameplay, amazingly detailed firearms, great sound design, simple but slick graphics,  incredible game for being made at a 7-day game jamCons: Not much actual game, only 3 weapons, no updates/game abandoned, game would/could be so much better if the game got a minor update (more/different enemies, new map/level, new/more weapons).I found out about this game through Rockleesmile (the youtuber who has a show called Indie Impressions).  This game is absolutely amazing considering it was built in just 7 days. There are AAA games that cost millions of dollars and years of development that aren’t as fun, intriguing, detailed, and solid as Receiver.  Receiver’s not a perfect game and it’s definitely lacking in the content department (meaning it could really use more things to do, weapons to use, and greater enemy variety).  The “plot” if you can call it that is incomprehensible; as you make your way through the randomly generated levels you find (amongst more ammo usually) tape cassettes which contain the “story” of what’s going on.  There is an order to these tapes but I’ve never gotten more than 4 (there are 11 total) during a single run and although there is a proper order in which listening to them forms a coherent story (I think anyways) but in my experience they are always out of order therefore making the “story/plot” meaningless.  The real draw for this game is the HIGHLY detailed weapons.  The guns are the most accurate representations of guns I’ve ever experienced in a videogame (that was the point of the game; to create hyper realistic weapon/gun action).  Each bullet must be loaded into the gun (whether in a magazine or in the drum of a revolver) safeties disengaged, slides cocked, etc.  The in game representation of the M1911A1 Colt .45 pistol is exceptionally accurate because I actually own one IRL and it’s amazing how well represented it is in the game.  The sound design too is excellent.  The music swells and is intense when enemies are present, and sufficiently “sci-fi” and groovy while exploring.  The sounds of the weapons firing is quite satisfying, each shot feels “real” and each different type of ammo (9mm, .45 ACP, or .38 special) sounds/feels unique.  The level of detail in Receiver is exceptional and mind blowing, even more so when faced w/ the fact that it was made from scratch in 7 days.  These devs definitely have earned the price of the game, if you’re any kind of fan of firearms this game is worth checking out, you will very likely be impressed.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												Fascinating experiment, sort of a survival horror FPS that runs light on visceral horror but heavy on tension.  The detailed gun mechanics were frustrating at first but gave a sense of accomplishment once I got the patterns down.  (I often found myself compulsively checking the colt/glock to make sure a round was chambered and spinning the revolver cylinder "for luck" before snapping it shut.)The randomized tapes remind me a little of Dear Esther's non-linear storytelling (if someone did a Dear Esther/Receiver mashup, I would buy that in a heartbeat :)If you are frustrated by making mistakes and learning through trial-and-error, you will probably not enjoy this game.  To get anywhere, you will die and restart.  A lot.  Bullets are scarce, and you die in one hit, so it's not a game for people who want to rush around blowing things away.  Much of my enjoyment of the game came from efficient use of those scarce bullets and outwitting the drones.If you are interested in game design and how design decisions and minimalist storytelling affect the player experience, this is definitely worth a look.

Posted: May 18, 2014
												DISCLAIMER: I know this game was created in seven days. That's amazing and all, and it's priced right, but I still hate it.This game was fun--at first. The only things going for Receiver are the 3 guns you can play around with, and the mechanics that require multiple key commands to execute a reload. After that, the game falls flat on its face.The story revolves around you spawning randomly in a dystopian apartment building with a gun in your hands. You have either a Colt 1911, a Glock 17, or a Smith and Wesson Model 10, as well as a random number of bullets. You have two enemy types, a stationary rotating machine gut turret and a flying drone electrocutor, neither of which are very difficult to kill or outwit. They're super-boring and get tiresome very quickly once you figure out the weak points on each one.Your objective is to search, collect, and listen to 11 tapes that are littered about the complex without dying, either from falling, getting shot or electrocuted, or, as I discovered minutes before writing this review, shooting yourself in the foot. That, for me, was the final straw in playing this game over and over and over just to try and beat it.The game is extremely challenging, and not in a good way. There is no map or GPS or way of finding out just where you are, leading to LOTS of backtracking. There is no health system; one shot or lethal fall, and you're dead. There are no checkpoints, so you start all over when the game freezes up or you get killed. That alone is reason enough not to buy Receiver; to have to start all the way back at zero after making so much progress.Receiver does one thing and does it really well--it gives the player more control over their weapons, more so than in most other FPSs out there. Is that enough of a reason to pay $4.99 for it? Yes; as long as you don't expect anything more than that from the game, you'll be A-Okay.

Posted: October 13, 2013
												Whether your looking  for a realistic Indie FPS, a fun and exciting new twist on first-person shooters, or a realistic gun simulator with a classic arcade feel, there is something for everybody in a game that can be fun but rather burdensome oftentimes.The game features realistic gun errors, (i.e jamming, safe reloads, and bullets getting stuck in the cylinder) excellent gun mechanics, and awesome bullet physics. The game while fun, has some major performance issues. I will often be on an important part of the game when suddenly I start to get major lag. This should not be happening on a game like this, as the graphics are not even that good. This takes away from much of the game's fun. When the game is not lagging (something which is a rare commodity) it is extremely fun to play. When you encounter a flying mind tech you feel this true sense of fear for your life as you either fight or run. Shooting and reloading the gun is rather interesting because every single part of the gun is controllable. While this adds uniqueness to the game it slows the pace down considerably and has nothing to help speed it up.The verdict: An exciting and adrenaline pumping experiment that is hindered majorly by its massive performance issues. While the game is fun to play it badly needs to be optimized. If you have beast gaming computer or something "good enough" to run most games, then I would definitely recommend picking this up!Overall rating: 6/10Presentation: 5/10Gameplay: 7/10Graphics: 5/10Sound: 8/10Difficulty: 8/10Lasting Appeal: 6.5Overall rating: 6/10

Posted: October 6, 2014
												7 DAYSthat's all this was alotted for when the project was made, as a competition piece of brand new un explored gaming, i find this to be very good, i got it for free, as i expect most people to "want" something for their money, you'll be paying for something you don't want, on the whole, this game is fantastic, i find it very engaging and simple, yet complex and boring, the idea behind the game is brilliant, if you want to play a game you have no familiarity with, brand new controls and cool level design, despite the lack of textures, i suggest you try this game, i can't stress the inginuity with the 7 days this was made in.some say the levels design is repetitive and boring, but that's the thing, how would YOU react to finding yourself here? having to operate a gun with it's proper details, defend yourself for unkown reasons, the tension, the audio the atmosphere in this game can get really intense, as a side note there is cheats available to help with completion if you find the game comes across unfair and your bullets don't hit where you fire. and the slow motion cheat can make things look really cool.the god mode makes it really easy but alllows for mistakes to be corrected, don't forget in this scenario, you are vulnerable, not a regenerating cybernetic undefeatable mass of intelligence like most games make you out to be, and death is death, it's a restart and a new starting point, new gu and new magazine set, so the start can be unfair with a few bullets and a mag or great with 3 mags and a ton of bullets. the controls are also available for on screen play, no pausing needed but you need to be quick if you are being chased.good luck.

Posted: October 10, 2014
												More a gun operation simulator than a shooter, Reciever replaces the standard “Press R to Reload” with a full tour of all the moving parts. First, the magazine must be ejected and the gun holstered. Only then can the magazine be fed with bullets and loaded back into the gun which then must be racked before a bullet ever reaches the chamber. It can be a difficult and confusing task, especially with the pressure of an active turret nearby, but it is satisfying and forces a level of interaction with the weapon beyond the normal point-and-click to remove obstacles. The scarcity of both supplies and fancy textures keeps the focus on that relationship between the player and the gun mechanics. The only distraction, other than the constantly looming threat of permanent death, is the tapes littered throughout the randomly generated terrain which either serve to set up a backdrop for the action or just spout the sort of nonsense you've come to expect from the street corner next to the liquor shop. The whole thing's over before a conclusion can be reached on that subject which just left me wishing someone would take this near blank slate and mod in a context for it all.

Posted: March 5, 2014
												Receiver is a rather simple (on the surface) FPS game. Receiver's main objective is to find cassette tapes that tell a story of the society and troubles of the world, as well as how to operate a firearm. The gunplay is fantastic, for it focuses on semi-realism. Destroy the kill-bots with precise firing by hitting key parts such as the cameras, engine, battery, or (in the case of the flying taser-bots) the rotor. After the threat is neutralized, you should check your ammol without having a silly HUD, the game forces/allows you to pull the magazine from your gun (or open slide out the cylinder) to check how much ammo you have left. Maybe you emptied the clip and recently reloaded your gun, but you're not sure you got one in the chamber. Simply pull the slide back halfway, and take a peek! Overall, Receiver is easily worth the sale price of $5, and definitely more, although the price helps in the fun. 10/10

Posted: April 28, 2015
												Reciever is a short game with fun gun mechanics. It was initially made in about 42 hours or so for a competition, and it shows. The environemnts are repeated heavily, the textures are bare, and it feels kinda cobbled together. That being said, the gun mechanics are its main selling point, and you're probably not thinking of buying it for its minimalistic style. So, let's address that aspect of the game.The gun mechanics are very complex and realistic, and unique because of that. Now - to be clear - I've never owned nor fired a gun. However, I do have a pretty decent grasp on the basics of how modern ballistic weapons work, as should most people. The game portrays them accurately as far as i know, but someone that actually owns a firearm might say otherwise. Reloading the weapon is a complicated multi-step process, priming the weapon must be done for it to fire, and you even have to turn of the safety. There is also no ammo counter, you have to count shots or look at your clip for a vague idea of how many bullets you have left. You have to make sure a round is actually chambered, and cocking the gun while a bullet is in the chamber already ejects the perfectly good, unused round that you then have to pick up in embarrassment. If you're looking at buying this game for the mechanics of it, I'd say it's probably worth it.However, if you want a game that is more than just a bare-bones proof of concept slapped together over a short amount of time and sold on steam, then you might wish to look elsewhere. While it's not expensive by any stretch of the imagination, it is - however - still 5 bucks. While I've derived a lot of enjoyment from messing around with it - as it's a rogue like - there's a distinct lack of a real story, varied enemies, guns - even through there's 3 now - and other content you'd expect from a normal game. It's good, but if you don't think the shooting mechanics are interesting enough to warrent a purchase, then you should probably think hard about whether or not it's worth it. I won't tell you that you won't end up liking it - because you might - but know that when you get into this thing it's not to reach reality A.

												Fantastic game considering it was built in 7 days and goes on sale for $1-3 on occasion.  While some find this game boring or hard, I find it addictive because I have yet to find all the tape and the game actually presents a challenge.  It breaks mussle memory on how to use a gun by teaching you how a gun actually works and binding every little thing to a key. Posted: March 4, 2014
												I never write reviews for games, but this one deserves it. One thing first:If you like standard FPS controls, hit ESC in-game, and check the box that says "lock gun to center of screen"; this will get rid of the annoying 'swivel aim' when you bring up the iron sights. Once I did this, I had an easier time of dealing with enemies.Onto the game:It may have strange graphics, but this game is amazing. It's brutally difficult, and when you panic you screw up firing your gun. I'm very familiar with firearms, but I initially kept forgetting to rack the slide in the 1911 or Glock if I spawned with a magazine in. The 1911 can get you when you forget to♥♥♥♥♥♥the hammer, too. It's really amazing how in-depth the weapon controls are. Being able to load a magazine, chamber a round, unload that mag, and load a fresh one is awesome; not many games let you +1 a gun. Being able to freely spin the revolver's cylinder is also very fun. I had some good times just playing Russian Roulette with glass panes. I have only played an hour of this game so far, and I haven't gotten very far, or even really figured out what I'm supposed to be doing, but the gun mechanics are keeping me intently occupied.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												A simplistic yet endearing game. The plot is barebones, relayed to you only through collectible tapes hidden throughout the world. The game takes place in a seemingly abandoned building inhabited by robots and machines out to kill you. This is where the gameplay shines. It's an FPS, yes, but you only carry a single pistol with VERY limited ammunition. In addition to this, you have to go through EVERY single step of using a gun. You'd have to manually insert the rounds into the magazine, insert the magazine, release the safety, chamber the round, and take aim all manually. Reloading has no automation whatsoever. Even then, you have to keep track of any ammo you have by checking the magazine as well as checking the chamber manually. On top of that, you die in one hit, while enemies take two to three hits on average.That's the main premise of the game, the interaction with the firearm. It's a bit shaky at first, but when you reload a gun just through muscle memory alone, it's the greatest feeling.Oh yeah. One more thing. You're gonna need that flashlight. If you don't spawn with it, you best find it.

												This can't actually be called a game, for the state in which it was left after the 7 day challenge in which it was made. 												Ok, Lets get one thing straight: The underlying IDEA of the game is genius. The execution of it however, is rather lacking. The flow of the game is a slow and enjoying pace. However, the procedural generation of the levels, loot, and enemies makes things rather frustrating. You can spawn completely set with enough ammo to take on the world, or none at all. I once spawned with a Glock with no mags. Awesome. Other times I have been spawned in the middle of some warehouse-like room next to 3 turrets. Great! The game is good, but it feels like they stopped right after the challenge ended and didnt round out the edges that make this such a flawed game. It just feels... empty. I immediately opened the in-game help menu, looked at the keys, and immediately was confused. For being a realistic-wanna-be for gun mechanics, how the hell am I supposed to check if there is a round in the chamber without pulling back the slide all the way and ejecting the round instead? Why cant I re-bind keys? Typically, any gun-lover such as myself would have LOVED to rebind the safey/Slide lock to a key on our mice - more specifically one of the thumb buttons as that is the finger you use for it. There are plenty of inconsistencies with the controls too. E to open the cyllinder on the revolver, but on the mag fed pistols, it just drops the mag in your hand, whereas Z takes out and inserts the mag. Why should I have 2 different keys for opening and closing the cyllinders? Why cant R just toggle the state instead of E to open and R to close? The entire button layout is just completely horrendous and poorly implemented - which is a shame because it could have been SO much better.I really wanted to enjoy the game, but the unfair swarm of enemies, constant control issues, and horrible balance for loot spawn just makes the level of frustration with this game a total waste of potential.This review is as of playing 0.8 Hours. I am trying to enjoy the game further, and cuz I simply enjoy playing with the guns - not neccesarily the game itself though.EDIT: So I finally beat the damn thing. And I only think the reason I did it was due to the fact that I got a lucky RNGeezus that decided to watch my back. Loads of bullets, spawned with 3 mags, and only turrets and no air drones. What you get when you win was very... disappointing.

Posted: June 9, 2013
												The fact that a game made in seven days is more unique, interesting, and entertaining than  modern AAA FPS is really telling about the genre and the gaming industry as a whole... Completely risk-averse, just like Hollywood.Receiver is quite an experimental game, and the trailer pretty much shows the entire scope of it, so I'll spare talking too much about gameplay. The handling and bullet physics of the guns are the game's main selling points, and they perform quite well. You need to load every magazine yourself, eject spent casings, bullets will ricochet if fired at bad angles, etc. etc.The two enemies shown in the trailer are the only two enemies in the game, the flying drones which rush you really fast and try and stun you and the turrets. Both kill you in one hit. Not much of a variety at all, but it doesn't really need one. The drones clearly test your reflexes and the turrets your marksmanship. It could use one more to test handling in some way but that seems impossible to implement unless it somehow magically jammed your gun.All in all it works together quite nicely. The levels and your starting equipment are randomly generated and there's always some unique challenge to overcome. That said the level generation could use a few tweaks... as it tends to make impossibly hard levels with 0 ammo and about 8 turrets down a single one way path. The way you see the developers shooting multiple rounds at things in the trailer? Not a good idea. You generally want to take everything out in one shot if you can because ammo is very, very scarce, though you may get lucky! Aside from the obvious crappy graphics (the game seems to have problems with V-sync, by the way) that is my only negative.7/10 seems about right.

Tension-filled, easy to get into, but hard-to-adjust-to controls, Receiver is well worth the money.

Posted: August 7, 2013
												Receiver is a game that anyone interested in gaming and the feeling of accomplishment should play.  Regrettably, I think I am now done with it.  This is a game with a steep learning curve and tremendous difficulty, the latter being something I am not particularly fond of in games.  But few games gave me such a strong feeling of accomplishment as when I learned to use the gun and take out enemies successfully.  There are some simple fixes that I think would benefit the game; slowing down the flying enemies which move at unforgiving speeds and having more warning about nearby enemies in general would allow me to have survived countless accidental deaths, which often seemed unfair rather than my own fault.  Protip, play with the options before you get into it, specifically turning on the option to lock the gun to the center of the screen.  All in all I highly recommend the game as a piece of interest, and I only wish that the game was still supported and seeing updates.

Posted: December 9, 2014
												This game is more a less a rogue-like tech demo. The price and the videos about it should reflect that to players.The premise of the game is that players will start off with a pistol, it could be a revolver base or a magazine based pistol.  From there, you are going around looking for recordings to find out more about the area that you are trying to escape.  Casing point though, it takes a backseat to the mechanics.One of the core concepts of this "demo" is that it is fairly thrilling to reload a pistol all the way through by manipulating each of its mechanisms in a fluid manner under pressure. The hammer, the chamber, the loading or unloading of the magazine all have dedicated buttons which gives this demo a big learning curve because it's not as simple as press "R" to reload your magazines anymore.The revolvers are simpler and take less time to learn to reload and ready for firing.As for the other parts of the game, the elements of the environment and the mechanical enemies are simple polygons.  It gets the job done.

Posted: October 15, 2013
												This is a really interesting game, which makes the gun mechanics of "hard" military sims such as the Arma series look absolutely primitive. Here you have to manually reload a limited supply of rounds into clips and chamber rounds before they can be fired. As someone who's actually fired real world weapons, it's nice to see the real world mechanics of actually handing rounds and guns replicated faithfully in a videogame. There's no one button, instant reload here; and the game's all the better for it. The premise of the game is also interesting, too, and the procedurally generated levels allied to one-hit vulnerabilty and permadeath add lots of replayability - but  if there's one major flaw, the AI is *way* too twitchy. As an experiment in replicating real world gun mechanics in a virtual world, Receiver is an unqualified success - by playing it you'll gain a much greater understanding and respect for how handguns actually work - but as a game, slightly less agressive AI would greatly enhance the experience for those of us who don't have the reflexes of house flies on amphetamines.

Posted: September 18, 2013
												A must have.An FPS that lets you take full control of your weapon. No more R to reload, no more resupplying by walking over ammo, etc. One button to pull the slide, one to eject the magazine, one to put a round into the magazine, one to chamber a round, one to engage safety, one to eject a round, one to pick stuff up, one to fire... it does have a bit of a learning curve, but I can tell you it's really worth it. Once you've mastered your weapon, using it will be thrilling. You have to shoot drones that'll try to kill you. Once you die, you start over on a new, randomly generated map (well, more like existing rooms put together in a random order). It also has an eerie backstory and "quest", of which I'm not going to reveal anything other than you collect cassette tapes and listen to them.If you have ever played FPS games, corridor shooters, shoot-em-ups, whatever, you need to play this game.If you like guns, you absolutely need to play this game. I'm not especially into firearms, but this game made me more interested in them :)Cons: The game was made in about ten days (for a game jam), so it's far from polished. The graphics won't astonish you (think minimalistic Unity3D), and there are some optimization problems, but overall it's still a very enjoyable and definitely unique experience.Oh, and it's made by the Wolfire guys who are like the best indie devs ever. So buy it nao.

Posted: September 25, 2014
 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine  PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this gameALSO NOTE: If I (the reviewer) have played a game that has less than 1 hour of gameplay and is recommended, means that I did not enjoy it but it passed a bit of my level of expectations! Think twice before buying/playing this game(This only applies to some games that have been recommended, not all, please read above before reading the review below) Receiver is... meh, it is not a terrible game nor is it a fantastic game!The game was developed by Wolfire Games (the same developer as Overgrowth) for the 7-day FPS challenge, and I must say for 7 days, they have created quite a stable game.The gun mechanics and the realism of the gun handling is amazing, the animations for the guns are fantastic, well done to Wolfire Games!BUT the game has some serious issues:-The level of difficulty: The game is really hard, from beginning to end, once you die, it resets everything (kind of like a rogue-like game), it is randomly generated, the enemies are really hard and annoying and the tapes that you have to  collect are very hard to find. Once you found a number of tapes and you get killed, you lose everything, which can be quite annoying, as the enemies are difficult and sometimes just appear out of nowhere!The controls for the guns: They are extremely awkward, I can understand why they did it, because in real life, to handle a gun, it takes time and practice, but for game it is pretty annoying, the game does help you with a list of controls, but if you run out of a magazine with one of the game's enemies running after you/shooting at you, I don't think the list of controls will help in dire need of refilling a magazine with ammo, whilst focusing on the game and the list of controls (not for me anyway)! Level design: Although the levels are quite good, they can get really confusing and it put me off after a whileAmmo: Ammo is really scarce, and you can hardly find any ammo anywhere, once you lost your ammo, and you meet one of the enemies of the game, your ♥♥♥♥edCompatibility: The game is awful with compatibility, the game is developed with the Unity3D engine, and its frame rate just drops drastically in some areas, whereas other Unity3D games I've played, run fantastically on my gaming PCLevel of detail: The level of detail (excluding the gun designs) is bland, and very incomplete, I can understand for a 7-day development time, but Wolfire Games could of after the game finished the 7-day FPS challenge make the game a bit more detailed, but it seems that Wolfire Games just abandoned the game after they finished the 7-day FPS challengeNow to the recommendation, for its full price, I would not recommend it, BUT if it is either in a sale, price drop, giveaway, gift or even given to you as a free game then I would recommend it. RECOMMENDED :)  Provided it is in a sale, price drop, giveaway, gift or even given to you as a free game, otherwise...  NOT RECOMMENDED :(  For its full price

Posted: April 18, 2014
												A brilliant love child between a Slenderman-esque collection, 'LifeForce Tenka' future dystopic, and 'The Matrix'-like-conspiracy, rolled into a handgun simulation game.You have been dropped into an unfamiliar and alien world where all you have is your gun, an appropriate magazine (if you're not wielding the Smith & Wesson), and a random assortment of supplies. Your goal is to collect the tapes scattered throughout the game and reach a state of awakening, piecing your story together as you avoid the games treacherous falls and gun-totting, tazer-wielding "Kill-Bots".No two games you play will be the same, with randomised drops of tapes and ammo, unrelenting and uncomprimising sentry bots, and vivid and vague worlds randomly generated, which will leave you fearing, focused, frustrated, or flying-high, as you attempt to scrounge whatever little ammunition and disordered 8-tracks strewn among the highrise fortresses of a cyberpunk dystopia.

Posted: March 31, 2014
												Receiver is probably the most satisfying, and purest (in the sense of gameplay) pick-up-and-play title.  Not only is it directly based on your own readyness/carefulness, but also based on how you know either of the three weapons that you randomly tote, in various states, reserve ammo and placement.  No two playthroughs are the same; each are generated in different ways.The enemies are one of two, a spinning sentry turrent or the more dangerous air drone.  Each having there own weakpoints to learn and behaviour to adapt to.You can only take one bullet, which also brings up another thing about Reviever.  You die from one shot, stun or a two story drop.The weapons, the Glock 18, M1911A1 and Colt Revolver behave realistically aswell.  On top of that, reloading becomes a very important routine, that they all differ.  You need to not only extract the magazine of the 1911, but also swap magazines, load in the cartridges, either hit the slide lock or rack it.  With such a minimalist HUD, you need to count your shots, to drop a mag for inspection.Also nice touches such as the revolver casings expanding within the cylinder after use, requiring several attempts at the extractor and so on.All this makes such a satisfying 'in-betweener' game.  Thoroughly recommended.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												You shoot robots and find tapes, ammo, and flashlights. To most people that's the whole game. I see it as more of a "Hey kids, you think just because you play Call of ♥♥♥♥ing duty all day and whenever your parrents tell you to get off for whatever reason you♥♥♥♥♥♥and murder them, that you know how to use a gun? Well, show us! Come play this game called reciever, and remember, anything besides bullets and yourself that moves, shoot it!"This game does not have a health bar, but it's still easy to know how much health you have. This is because no matter where you are shot, you die on the first bullet, like in real life! Imagine that in a video game. So basically if you are alive you have 100 health (or 99 if you're a hard core metroid fan).There is no ammo counter. You need to count how many bullets are in a mag, and keep track of the ammount of bullets you fire. Or, just regularly check in on your ammo. You can either put in a new mag, assuming you spawn with one with actual ammo, or just insert bullets into the mag itself. As for the revolver, i just eject all bullets, and pick the ones i droped back up and put them in the gun. Easy.There are three guns. The Revolver, the Glock, and the 1911. I am partial to the Revolver, the glock is ok, and the 1911 is abysmal.The Revolver is exactly what it sounds like. It has 6 round capacity, and occasionally needs a hammer to be pulled down. The Glock is a pistol with a huge clip of which yet I am still unaware the full capacity too. If i were to wager a guess, i'd have to say maybe 32 bullets? It has two fireing modes. Semi automatic, and fully automatic. TIP: If you plan on actually trying to live, keep ammo, and ultimatly win the game, do not use fully automatic mode. It eats ammo like a mother humper and kicks like a kangaroo, and I can garentuee you next to no bullets will ever hit your target. This is not a game where you should "spray and pray".The 1911 is a terrible gun. It has so many standards compared to the other guns, that it's almost like a punishment to have. The max capacity for a mag is 8, and the bullets are as affective as blank bullets shooting something five miles away... right next to a kill drone. For some reason, unlike all the other guns, it has a safety. It also has a hammer which is really annoying to use, and I don't know if this is only me, but I can load a full mag, chamber a bullet, have the safety off and have the hammer down, be fully prepared, but the gun WILL... NOT... FIRE....... but you know, this only happens when there is a tape right in front of me.There are two types of killdrones in the game. The Hover-drone, and the killdrone turret. The hoverdrone is really annoying because it makes a really stupid sound, bounces all over the place, making it just about impossible to hit sometimes, and it has a really annoying sounding tazer that kills you in one hit, because as we all know, tazers kill people in under a second people. The killdrone turret is a sationary revolving turret with unlimited ammo that fires bullets that kill you in one hit. That's kinda self explanitory.Overall i think this game is great, just damn hard, and occasionally annoying if you have the 1911. The mechanics are great, like how you have to repeatedly press your walk key to run. This can be bad because sometimes it can just activate at any random time, but you know, this only happens when your right next to a  CLIFF... and it doesn't matter if you're crouched. If you start double tappin' that walk key you get right the ♥♥♥♥ up and start running. Even sometimes if you DON'T, it's like the computer say's "NOPE." and it kills you in a way that makes it seem like it's your fault. But all the con's in this game can be overlooked in one short sentence.The game was made in only seven days. For a game like this, thats incredible. I wish though that I could see wolfire games finish this and make it a whole game with more mechanics, fix some bugs, add new enemies, etc.I rate this game 8/10 for being perfect when you aren't running off cliffs for no reason and you don't have a 1911.As for the tapes, I'll let you listen to them yourself.

Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is a simple game with a really cool idea. Its an FPS where you control every action involving firing, loading and unloading your gun. It takes an action that is often one button press in games and turns it a lot of steps, like pressing E to remove the magazine, then ~ to hostler the weapon, then z to put any spare bullets you find back into the magazine, ~ again to equip the gun again, Z to slide the magazine back into the gun, and then T to load a round into the chamber. Some guns have you press V to change firing modes or to turn on or off the saftey. It might sound an annoying ammount of things to deal with but when you are doing it successfully its pretty rad. Its a really short game with only 2 enemies and maybe 3 guns but its a unique enough experience that its worth a buy.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												A simplistic yet endearing game. The plot is barebones, relayed to you only through collectible tapes hidden throughout the world. The game takes place in a seemingly abandoned building inhabited by robots and machines out to kill you. This is where the gameplay shines. It's an FPS, yes, but you only carry a single pistol with VERY limited ammunition. In addition to this, you have to go through EVERY single step of using a gun. You'd have to manually insert the rounds into the magazine, insert the magazine, release the safety, chamber the round, and take aim all manually. Reloading has no automation whatsoever. Even then, you have to keep track of any ammo you have by checking the magazine as well as checking the chamber manually. On top of that, you die in one hit, while enemies take two to three hits on average.That's the main premise of the game, the interaction with the firearm. It's a bit shaky at first, but when you reload a gun just through muscle memory alone, it's the greatest feeling.Oh yeah. One more thing. You're gonna need that flashlight. If you don't spawn with it, you best find it.

Posted: July 14, 2014
												Despite the flaws included in being a 7 day FPS entry, I still seem to be drawn back to Reciever. It's frustrating, because at some point you'll forget to add bullets to your magazine or you'll stumble while trying to run from one of the many hellish floating zappy robots that inhabits Reciever's levels, but the simple element of having to treat your gun like a real firearm makes Reciever something else. It gains more imersiveness than could be added by having Tomb Raider (2013)'s visuals or Half Life 2's character animations. It makes the game more of a realization that you are not the killing machine Call of Duty has trained you to be. It shouts in your face, "you can't even run from a fan with a taser strapped to it!"It might also be the quick loading time that makes Reciever an easy game to get into, usually I only end up playing 15 minutes before getting frustrated that I got the revolver again (I don't really like the revolver, it loses the complexity that the 1911 and the Glock have), only to come back half an hour later for more. Reciever may not really be a game, but it certainly shows that if you add complexity to any game mechanic, the game might be more interesting.

												This game is an FPS. That deserves more praise for its work.What's so great about this "Call of Duty ripoff"?For an FPS, the game doesn't focus on shooting. Not at all.It focuses on taking your time. And focuses on being as technical as possible with its reloading system.Lets make an example right here.To reload a revolver. Button 1 to show cylinderButton 2, 2-3 times to empty the cylinderButton 3 about 6 times to put in each individual bullet.Button 4 to close cylinder.With a pistol.Button 1 to take out clip.Button 2 to put away gun.Spam button 3 to put in each individual bullet into clip.Button 2 to take out gun again.Button 4 to put in clip.Button 5 to♥♥♥♥♥♥the gun, and put the bullet in place, ready to fire. (If needed.)Put that in a situation where you are in need of reloading, and conserving ammo. Then you have Reciever.This is a good thing, for it introduces a new type of strategy to your combat, and how you play the game. Unlike Run-And-Gun Simulator.The story is very..Interesting. I am not going to spoil it for you. But its not something to write home about, in my eyes. But its something that is newBut okay, every game has cons to it. What are some in this game?1.)  1-Hit-Kills. I can sort of forgive this aspect. Since the game does explain that you are horribly weak and ill. And you woke up on the top of a building, which layout you cannot recognise.2.) No more than 2 enemies. I don't care if you spam enemy 1 in one place. With some enemy 2 sprinkled on. We have 2 enemies. And that is lazy.3.) I wouldn't say this is a problem with the game. But I'm going to compare SC: Chaos Theory with this subject. Here we go.The lag. The horrible framerate. Its hard to control your guns and your escape with it. It ticks me off to be trying to run away from a flying tazer, and have a horrible FPS while doing so. Now, lets compare it with Chaos Theory. SC:CT looks very AAA Title for an Xbox to PC port. And with these quite stunning graphics, the game runs like butter on a hot pan. Reciever just feels clunky with this. And I've set everything on low. Even windowing the game didn't help.Thats pretty much all the complaints I have on this game, but those complaints still don't ruin the game that much. It is still enjoyable. And a good time-waster.

Posted: October 5, 2014
Receiver is a simple game in design, but that simplicity goes a long way in the amount of effort it takes to move forward.Imagine Metal Gear Solid mixed with Rainbow Six, along with the undertones of the world controlling you. This might be the best idea for Receiver. The game is very barebones in gameplay, but it's exactly that element that changes how you play the game compared to other first-person shooters. This is hardcore FPS at its finest, and you'll be shocked to know just how much work you need to put in to get through it all.It has a roguelight element to it, which to this game, means you have a small variety of guns that you will spawn with, along with a specific quantity of ammunition, as well as magazines, based on the weapon. The equipment also has randomized properties. You may need to prime the weapon, you may need to turn the safety off, you may need to ensure that your six-shooter is full in all barrels. It goes a long way, and over time, you'll be adapted to this, which shows another element that the game has: it disciplines you. You WILL die if you neglect one detail, so don't overlook anything.Speaking of dying, you will die. You will probably die a lot. That's because it's a one-hit kill game. You get hit at all, it's over, and you start anew. Doesn't seem new, huh? Well, admittedly not, but there's several details the game focuses on for you to succeed. Specific hit zones on your enemies. Blind spots. Corners, timing, even your gun has an arc after a certain distance that warrants you be a bit more methodical... Until you're spotted. Now you need to find and hit their weak spot. Miss the spot? Pray your next shot doesn't. It does? Say goodbye. And that is yet another element: Be calm. If you don't, you risk missing the shot.There's actually a few weak spots on all your enemies, and it sets a slight dynamic for how your enemy is defeated, and what happens next. You can shoot out the tazer on the cyclone bots, and that may leave you annoyed to hell and back as they fly around, distracting you and wasting your ammo as they fly around you, and through you, which is disorienting as all hell.You must be tactical, conservative, watchful, and completely aware. Your ammo can fade quickly, your magazines will be emptied rapidly, and if you don't run when you need to, you'll screw up, and fail to reload as you attempt to. The controls go a long way to emphasize that as well. It definitely doesn't feel traditional, which makes sense, because it isn't. It isn't even comparable to games like Takedown: Red Sabre or Insurgency. You go at one speed, and crouching does little except expand your mobility among the level. The focus is completely on your location relative to the enemies, and your defense/offense.Remember my explaining the game in layman's terms? That sets the story's tone too. The story is as such: You are a receiver, left in a sort of dream state or second reality. It's in the second reality that you've learned of the first reality, and that you are among a select few who survive a mind kill, destroying all who have been poisoned by corporations and media... all except the receivers. Your goal is to find 11 tapes scattered across the large building complex you're in, and be awakened, released from the body provided by the second reality, and brought forth to the first reality. Meanwhile, the corporation that executed the mind kill know of the receivers as well, and have designed more suitable forms of killing equipment to stop you in this second reality. If you die in the second reality, you are defined to be sealed, and cannot transcend to the first reality.Sounds crazy right? Well, it is. And again, you must find 11 tapes to transcend. Die, and you start over. Admittedly, it's a short game, but it's the difficulty and effort required that makes it worth it all. This game will not mess around. It's kill or be killed, and the game will make sure you are killed most.Final note, the game runs in the Unity3D engine, and surprisingly, is very bad in performance. I am shocked to know I get frame drops at 720p considering my specs. I've played Unity3D games that seemed far more demanding, and subsequently, perform much better than this game. Optimization faults, maybe? Either way, it isn't absolutely jarring, though framedrops can be bad if you find yourself in a risky situation.Overall, Receiver is probably the best hardcore FPS I've played this year, and probably of all time. It is simple, it focuses on the gunplay and strategy over all things, and bar controls, I can jump into this game and lose myself trying to make progress. It is an excellent grab, and if you didn't score it from Humble Bundle's free summer games, I think it is work every penny.

Posted: September 28, 2014
												This is not a game for everyone so wether someone recommended this game or not is almost entirely based on their taste in games and as such introduce some bias. That being said I will now impart some of my bias upon you. Reciever is an interseting game to say the least: no fancy graphics, minimal to no story, and a difficulty on a level of reality unobtainable by another game in this genre. Where Reciever truely shines is its delivery of narative through gameplay. There are a few (11 to be exacy) tapes throughout the game that have recordings on them that help explain the basic premise (the  goal of the game being to collect all 11), but the entirety of the feel and the lessons this game imparts (as any game worth its salts has at least some knowledge to impart) are based in its mechanics. This game takes guns very seriously: they kill. You take one bullet in this game and you die. Not to mention, as many comments will tell you, they ain't easy to operate (E, ~, 2, 3, ~, Z, R, F to reload?). Which leads to the conveince of theme. This game is hard. It is almost pointless to expect to win with any sense of ease; which is exactly what the narritive delivers. Without spoiling too much, you can essentially die endlessly in this game. A never ending cycle of death, failure and pain. Sounds like a message to me (not to mention the recordings speaking of a dystopian society). This coupled with the game's core mechanics being gun manipulation means that the narritive is almost entirely non-verbal, which is fantastic. Again, I do not reccommend this game to everyone (it is rather artsy and only made in a week), but is excellent for what it is, and I hope we can all learn something about guns from something other than Battlefield, CoD, Halo, etc where they're just tools. I wish you a good day, and thanks for listening to my ramblings on :) Cheers!

Posted: October 9, 2014
												Ah, Receiver. Don't let the complexity of the controls deter you from experiencing this marvelous game. Receiver is a game... well simulator... sort of... that focuses on knowing how to operate your weapons. Most FPS games you push a button to reload and it's done. BORING! In Receiver, the key is not to have good aim and press a button, it's to know the mechanism of the gun itself. You can't just push a button to change your clip, you must eject the mag, swap it for another, and place the new mag in the gun and chamber a bullet. Much more than just "Pressing a button." Receiver is an excellent game to play if you have knowledge of actual gun mechanics... and a PC with a good GPU. I'm sorry, but my laptop's Intel (R) HD GPU just doesn't cut it.

Posted: October 6, 2014
												7 DAYSthat's all this was alotted for when the project was made, as a competition piece of brand new un explored gaming, i find this to be very good, i got it for free, as i expect most people to "want" something for their money, you'll be paying for something you don't want, on the whole, this game is fantastic, i find it very engaging and simple, yet complex and boring, the idea behind the game is brilliant, if you want to play a game you have no familiarity with, brand new controls and cool level design, despite the lack of textures, i suggest you try this game, i can't stress the inginuity with the 7 days this was made in.some say the levels design is repetitive and boring, but that's the thing, how would YOU react to finding yourself here? having to operate a gun with it's proper details, defend yourself for unkown reasons, the tension, the audio the atmosphere in this game can get really intense, as a side note there is cheats available to help with completion if you find the game comes across unfair and your bullets don't hit where you fire. and the slow motion cheat can make things look really cool.the god mode makes it really easy but alllows for mistakes to be corrected, don't forget in this scenario, you are vulnerable, not a regenerating cybernetic undefeatable mass of intelligence like most games make you out to be, and death is death, it's a restart and a new starting point, new gu and new magazine set, so the start can be unfair with a few bullets and a mag or great with 3 mags and a ton of bullets. the controls are also available for on screen play, no pausing needed but you need to be quick if you are being chased.good luck.

Posted: October 17, 2014
												If there was a neutral button, I'd pick it. Reciever is an unfinished game that needs much polish, and very needed updates. This was made for 7FPS, but the overall expansions have only added little content. If this had been in development a few months longer it could have been pretty amazing (or if not made for a contest). The game is pretty low budget in the graphics department, the art style has a certain uniqueness to it that should attract only those who love minimalistic low-res 3D polygons.  The gameplay is what compansates for many other areas, and should keep you waiting around for more. The gun mechanics are with the most extensive realism I've seen protrayed that may other games haven't. The animations are well done surprisingly for the guns. Take all the ficton crap from other games and action movies you've seen and throw it out the window, Reciever will teach you proper. The story isn't that impressive but is interesting to listen to the tapes, it feels like a different storyline each time you collect the tapes in variating order. TLDR;SummaryGameplay- Provides some moments of action and is intense whenever nearing an enemy. Gun mechanics are over-the-top realistic. Graphics- Somewhat crappy, not without charm though. Audio- One cool song and some minor sound effects. Not much here. Animations- Very detailed and each gun has it's own flare. Story- Interesting but not engaging. Overall? I can't recommend Reciever as a whole, as it is flowing with flaws and horrible optimization. Very incomplete, but gameplay provides a few hours. Not the best deal for $5. Has some replayibility but is a decent game. Mostly just neat to see a showcase of gun realism, the main attraction to it.

Posted: October 10, 2014
												More a gun operation simulator than a shooter, Reciever replaces the standard “Press R to Reload” with a full tour of all the moving parts. First, the magazine must be ejected and the gun holstered. Only then can the magazine be fed with bullets and loaded back into the gun which then must be racked before a bullet ever reaches the chamber. It can be a difficult and confusing task, especially with the pressure of an active turret nearby, but it is satisfying and forces a level of interaction with the weapon beyond the normal point-and-click to remove obstacles. The scarcity of both supplies and fancy textures keeps the focus on that relationship between the player and the gun mechanics. The only distraction, other than the constantly looming threat of permanent death, is the tapes littered throughout the randomly generated terrain which either serve to set up a backdrop for the action or just spout the sort of nonsense you've come to expect from the street corner next to the liquor shop. The whole thing's over before a conclusion can be reached on that subject which just left me wishing someone would take this near blank slate and mod in a context for it all.

Posted: September 5, 2013
												Think you'd survive an action movie if you had a gun?Spoiler: No, no you wouldn't.This is the FPS equivalent of Super Meat Boy, and it has what are indisputably the most immersive gun mechanics of any game ever.The gameplay itself, outside of the gun mechanics is as simple as its minimalist aesthetic, but severely punishing for any misstep or corner left unchecked. It only takes one bullet to bring you down, and there's no going back. The game has a permadeath system, and any failure brings you back to square one with randomized equipment at a randomized spot of the randomized world.Tasks which would be simple motions for action heroes are challenging feats here. It may take you several playthroughs to swiftly reload a colt 1911a, but to finally accomplish a swift reload is incredibly satisfying.Receiver is Wolfire Games' submission for 7DFPS, and though it lacks polish, it's an extremely successful experiment in game design.

Posted: September 15, 2014
												 It's basically a first person shooter with very realistic gun mechanics. For example, to reload a revolver you first open the cylinder, then you separately take out the casings, you put the new ones in and you close it. You then have to pull back the hammer and stuff. It's quite complicated but it's a lot of fun once you get used to it. You also have to shoot ground sentries which shoot you and flying drones which electrocute you at a close range all whilst trying to find all 11 tapes.This game might not be for everyone but I personally really like this game. Also, I got this for free from Humble Bundle's End of Summer Sale so I'm not sure if it's worth its price.

Posted: October 9, 2014
												Ah, Receiver. Don't let the complexity of the controls deter you from experiencing this marvelous game. Receiver is a game... well simulator... sort of... that focuses on knowing how to operate your weapons. Most FPS games you push a button to reload and it's done. BORING! In Receiver, the key is not to have good aim and press a button, it's to know the mechanism of the gun itself. You can't just push a button to change your clip, you must eject the mag, swap it for another, and place the new mag in the gun and chamber a bullet. Much more than just "Pressing a button." Receiver is an excellent game to play if you have knowledge of actual gun mechanics... and a PC with a good GPU. I'm sorry, but my laptop's Intel (R) HD GPU just doesn't cut it.

Posted: October 24, 2014
												If you like indie games, super replayability, random generation to the max (weapon state, level, storyline order), dark often scary levels, and if you like games that you can master reciever is here to fill that empty spot in your stomach. If you don't like shooting boring robots and turrents then you'll be like me. In between this game. I love having only so many clips and even fewer bullets. Shooting and keeping track of how many bullets i have left. Scavaging the apartment rooms, sinks, toilets, and sometimes couch cushions for ammo. I love the feel of the game that i still am not completely sure what is going on and the story is literally given in a random order each time with few details leaving me with piecing it together gaining constant Ah Hah moments when i've achieved a fact! This game definately hits home with things i want in my game. Innovation on FPS, replayability, and i can play quick session, or long rides. I do only wish that i was not fighting robots and turrents. The literal most boring of enemies! Its a dark, lifeless, seperated world, cloaked in mystery! Why can't i face demons, or Mr. Smiths or something. Oh well, that is my one complaint and that should not turn you away! Hope you escape this dreamlike world with the knowledge of the reciever!

Posted: July 12, 2014
												Not worth full price, but an entertaining game. No saves, and one hit downs you, ending the game. Levels are randomised. And you have to manually use the parts of your gun (mapped to keys on your keyboard). It's a bit short, there are just two kinds of bad guy, and the graphics are poor and occasionally glitchy, but there's plenty of mileage in getting skilled and trying to fully complete the game in one playthrough.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												A simplistic yet endearing game. The plot is barebones, relayed to you only through collectible tapes hidden throughout the world. The game takes place in a seemingly abandoned building inhabited by robots and machines out to kill you. This is where the gameplay shines. It's an FPS, yes, but you only carry a single pistol with VERY limited ammunition. In addition to this, you have to go through EVERY single step of using a gun. You'd have to manually insert the rounds into the magazine, insert the magazine, release the safety, chamber the round, and take aim all manually. Reloading has no automation whatsoever. Even then, you have to keep track of any ammo you have by checking the magazine as well as checking the chamber manually. On top of that, you die in one hit, while enemies take two to three hits on average.That's the main premise of the game, the interaction with the firearm. It's a bit shaky at first, but when you reload a gun just through muscle memory alone, it's the greatest feeling.Oh yeah. One more thing. You're gonna need that flashlight. If you don't spawn with it, you best find it.

Posted: November 7, 2014
												I've sunk quite a bit into this game. It's not flawless, and bitterly unforgiving, but it's a challenge. There's a lot of games where you get "better", but more in the way that you warm up rather than actually getting better at the game itself. Reciever, however, is a game you get better at. You start off carefully studying the keybindings, fumbling with your weapon, but the more you play the more it becomes second nature.   Reciever is the QWOP or Surgeon Simulator of First Person Shooters. The fun isn't just in the game itself - The story and voice acting are well below part - The fun is in learning the controls and doing that little bit better every time.

Posted: April 27, 2014
												Receiver presents an interesting idea, but the presentation is not good. I am on a Linux system, and the low framerate makes the game basically unplayable. This is not because my machine doesn't meet the requirements for running it - there are many other people with the same issues. There is no option, on Linux, to change the resolution or graphic settings. Instead, you are given a small window to play in, which combined with the frequent framerate problems resulted in a less than enjoyable experience for me.  These problems, or so I have read, may be because the game uses the Unity engine.At $4.95 it is relatively inexpensive, but still I regret not purchasing another game instead.

Posted: September 15, 2014
												Ever wondered why firearms aren't pictured in a realistic way in games? This game is here to illustrate that. Instead of pressing R to reload, you go through the entire process of extracting empty shells and inserting bullets, as well as cocking, locking and loading and whatever else guns do, and it's /tedious/, especially with multiple enemies chasing you down.It's not a bad game as such, but it does illustrate how realism isn't always good. If you should buy and/or play it depends on how high your tolerance for fiddly, slow, realistic gunplay is. I wish I could choose "Maybe" as a recommendation.

Posted: September 30, 2013
												This is probably the most realistic shooter I've ever seen. It's not just some "point-and-shoot" game, you actually have to control each part of the gun. It's not as easy as "press R to reload", once you run out of bullets, you have to take out the magazine, put a new one in (or fill up the old one), put a bullet in the chamber, and♥♥♥♥♥♥the gun, and THEN fire. Every part of the gun mechanics in this game is pretty much exactly how you'd have to do it in real life (minus the whole finding random unused bullets lying everywhere). It's so hard to get used to at first (especially with all the lag), but this is still a really cool game for such a low price.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												Great fun for such a simple game (it was made in 7 days, which occasionally shows). Very difficult to complete (seems that quite few people have) since if you die, you have to start again, and 1 bullet will kill you. It's really tense since enemy/item/your spawning is random, so every time is like the first, having to check corners and move around tactically, with one wrong step meaning you have to start again.Realistic weapon handling too, which is fluid once you get the hang of the controls - you're in charge of each major moving part of the weapon (slide, safety, mag, hammer, etc,) so weapon knowledge is a big plus. Since a recent update you also may spawn with either an M1911, a revolver of some kind (a bit fiddly to reload, but quite simple otherwise), and a Glock 17 (with a full-auto mod, kind of pointless as ammo is so scarce).There's a couple playthroughs on YouTube, check 'em out!anyway GET IT IT'S SURPRISINGLY ACE

Posted: September 28, 2014
												This is not a game for everyone so wether someone recommended this game or not is almost entirely based on their taste in games and as such introduce some bias. That being said I will now impart some of my bias upon you. Reciever is an interseting game to say the least: no fancy graphics, minimal to no story, and a difficulty on a level of reality unobtainable by another game in this genre. Where Reciever truely shines is its delivery of narative through gameplay. There are a few (11 to be exacy) tapes throughout the game that have recordings on them that help explain the basic premise (the  goal of the game being to collect all 11), but the entirety of the feel and the lessons this game imparts (as any game worth its salts has at least some knowledge to impart) are based in its mechanics. This game takes guns very seriously: they kill. You take one bullet in this game and you die. Not to mention, as many comments will tell you, they ain't easy to operate (E, ~, 2, 3, ~, Z, R, F to reload?). Which leads to the conveince of theme. This game is hard. It is almost pointless to expect to win with any sense of ease; which is exactly what the narritive delivers. Without spoiling too much, you can essentially die endlessly in this game. A never ending cycle of death, failure and pain. Sounds like a message to me (not to mention the recordings speaking of a dystopian society). This coupled with the game's core mechanics being gun manipulation means that the narritive is almost entirely non-verbal, which is fantastic. Again, I do not reccommend this game to everyone (it is rather artsy and only made in a week), but is excellent for what it is, and I hope we can all learn something about guns from something other than Battlefield, CoD, Halo, etc where they're just tools. I wish you a good day, and thanks for listening to my ramblings on :) Cheers!

Posted: October 17, 2014
												If there was a neutral button, I'd pick it. Reciever is an unfinished game that needs much polish, and very needed updates. This was made for 7FPS, but the overall expansions have only added little content. If this had been in development a few months longer it could have been pretty amazing (or if not made for a contest). The game is pretty low budget in the graphics department, the art style has a certain uniqueness to it that should attract only those who love minimalistic low-res 3D polygons.  The gameplay is what compansates for many other areas, and should keep you waiting around for more. The gun mechanics are with the most extensive realism I've seen protrayed that may other games haven't. The animations are well done surprisingly for the guns. Take all the ficton crap from other games and action movies you've seen and throw it out the window, Reciever will teach you proper. The story isn't that impressive but is interesting to listen to the tapes, it feels like a different storyline each time you collect the tapes in variating order. TLDR;SummaryGameplay- Provides some moments of action and is intense whenever nearing an enemy. Gun mechanics are over-the-top realistic. Graphics- Somewhat crappy, not without charm though. Audio- One cool song and some minor sound effects. Not much here. Animations- Very detailed and each gun has it's own flare. Story- Interesting but not engaging. Overall? I can't recommend Reciever as a whole, as it is flowing with flaws and horrible optimization. Very incomplete, but gameplay provides a few hours. Not the best deal for $5. Has some replayibility but is a decent game. Mostly just neat to see a showcase of gun realism, the main attraction to it.

Posted: October 2, 2013
												1)  This game was made in 7 days.  Yes, 7.2)  It isn't pretty, but it works, and it works well.3)  It features realistic gun handling skills interms of loading and reloading.4)  An entirely randomized layout makes for (argueably) infinite replayability.5) If you get shot, you die.  No HP, no medkits, no healing potions.  D. E. D. Dead.   Receiver is based almost entirely upon realistic gun handling.  There is a distinct lack of surface textures, but you can't expect the Mona Lisa in a game that was made in such a short time.  I picked this game up on sale for about $2.50, but I would recommend buying it even at its original price.  Receiver takes a bit of getting used to, and the story line certainly isn't unique, but it is quite fun either way.  A perfet playthrough can see the game completed in about 30-40 minutes or so.  But it took me almost three hours of overall gameplay to reach that point.  For under a dollar per hour of enjoyment, I'm happy.

												Beginning players will find themselves figuring out the controls,finding out that a two foot drop can kill you, and that you can only take a bullet.Best of all, learn to work a handgun realistically; from manually inserting bullets intoa magazine, to loading the gun properly. Posted: September 2, 2016
												Receiver is a fun little FPS game which focuses on some pretty advanced and realistic gun control mechanics.You control every aspect of using whichever firearm you randomly spawn with from manually loading bullets into the magazine to removing the magazine and pulling the slide.You roam around the randomly generated map collecting bullets, flashlights and tapes which give you the insight into Receiver's background story. You win once you have collected all 11 tapes.In my opinion, the price of £4 is well worth the experience of originally trying to work out the weapon mechanics to roaming around taking out the hostile drones like a professional.There are also mods for Receiver which expand upon the original three firearms and include bug fixes and optimisations which I highly recommend.

Posted: June 27, 2013
												Reciever proves that it doesn't take great graphics or slick special effects to create an engaging and immersive gaming experience. The biggest feature of this game is its elaborate gun handling mechanics, what that means is we are the ones in total control of our weapons.  From pulling back the slide to manually loading rounds into an empty clip, it gives us a deep level of control, and the kind of adrenaline you'd believe you feel like you were in a real fire fight.   Now couple that with the games' randomized levels and unordered storytelling, Reciever puts this game high up on my recommendation list.

Posted: October 13, 2013
												Whether your looking  for a realistic Indie FPS, a fun and exciting new twist on first-person shooters, or a realistic gun simulator with a classic arcade feel, there is something for everybody in a game that can be fun but rather burdensome oftentimes.The game features realistic gun errors, (i.e jamming, safe reloads, and bullets getting stuck in the cylinder) excellent gun mechanics, and awesome bullet physics. The game while fun, has some major performance issues. I will often be on an important part of the game when suddenly I start to get major lag. This should not be happening on a game like this, as the graphics are not even that good. This takes away from much of the game's fun. When the game is not lagging (something which is a rare commodity) it is extremely fun to play. When you encounter a flying mind tech you feel this true sense of fear for your life as you either fight or run. Shooting and reloading the gun is rather interesting because every single part of the gun is controllable. While this adds uniqueness to the game it slows the pace down considerably and has nothing to help speed it up.The verdict: An exciting and adrenaline pumping experiment that is hindered majorly by its massive performance issues. While the game is fun to play it badly needs to be optimized. If you have beast gaming computer or something "good enough" to run most games, then I would definitely recommend picking this up!Overall rating: 6/10Presentation: 5/10Gameplay: 7/10Graphics: 5/10Sound: 8/10Difficulty: 8/10Lasting Appeal: 6.5Overall rating: 6/10

Posted: June 1, 2014
												Fascinating experiment, sort of a survival horror FPS that runs light on visceral horror but heavy on tension.  The detailed gun mechanics were frustrating at first but gave a sense of accomplishment once I got the patterns down.  (I often found myself compulsively checking the colt/glock to make sure a round was chambered and spinning the revolver cylinder "for luck" before snapping it shut.)The randomized tapes remind me a little of Dear Esther's non-linear storytelling (if someone did a Dear Esther/Receiver mashup, I would buy that in a heartbeat :)If you are frustrated by making mistakes and learning through trial-and-error, you will probably not enjoy this game.  To get anywhere, you will die and restart.  A lot.  Bullets are scarce, and you die in one hit, so it's not a game for people who want to rush around blowing things away.  Much of my enjoyment of the game came from efficient use of those scarce bullets and outwitting the drones.If you are interested in game design and how design decisions and minimalist storytelling affect the player experience, this is definitely worth a look.
