Posted: March 5, 2014
												This is a great game if you like messing with hand guns, but don't have any in real life.  If you do have one in real life, this game is the equivalent of learning how to translate what you know about operating a firearm to key strokes, running around some building-like place generated by a computer in 1992, and dying to robots.Some other reviews mentioned muscle memory, experiencing the fear of death, FUN, etc. I experienced none of that. Because the rooms all look essentially the same, and enemies are rather sparce, you start feeling as though you're running around in circles VERY quickly.  And you're essentially doing so looking for an excuse to operate your firearm.I do love the mechanics of handling the weapons.  Take this concept, add a few dozen different models (including long guns obviously), toss it into an online competitive environment, and it would be absolutely wonderful.  Skill curve for strategy, aiming, AND operating your equipment? Bliss.

Posted: August 22, 2013
												This game, while simplistic in graphics, is well worth the five bucks  - and then some. Unlike most FPS shooters where even the most gun-inept moron can be a hero, this game's mechanics puts a very tense spin on things by mimicing reality moreso than conventional shooters - such as no HUD, lack of "automatic" reloading, and the ability to take a bullet or two without collapsing. If caught unawares, the game is unforgiving. Get hit even once, and you are dead. This game also includes a system for reloading your magazines, which means unlike most FPS's where you just run around and magically pick up ammo in fully loaded, ready to use magazines, you will have to stop and load rounds into magazines by hand. Or remove them, depending on your preference - unless you're using the revolver. It's simple. It's tense. And I recommend it.

Posted: March 5, 2014
												Knowing your gun in this game is unlike any other. In games like CS:GO you master the recoil of a gun. In this, you master the gun itself. Anywhere from checking if a round is chambered, to manualy loading bullets into a gun. Very cool, very awesome, and very frustrating at times. Beware, get this game and it will eat your time.

Posted: March 5, 2014
												This is a great game, and I highly recommend it.It's really immersive and challenging, with a perma-death system that makes it very addictive. The scarcity of resources and the difficult combat both give the game this kind of survival-horror feel, but without jump-scares and through atmosphere instead. Unless you count the *beep* sound of a kill-drone locking onto you as a jump-scare, which you might by the end of a session. The controls are difficult to get used to, but it feels more realistic than traditional shooters. You're in complete control of every part of the gun, and fumbling under pressure while a tazerbot is flying toward you, getting ready to murder your face off, has this very authentic terror to it. In many ways, it feels more like an actual simulation of how well I personally would do under a similar situation rather than a video game, and it is very rewarding when your able to reload, shoot down 2 tazerbots and a turret, and reload again, all through muscle-memory without the help guide.The atmosphere in this game is thick enough to cut with a knife, and I really enjoyed getting immersed in the story and setting while listening tapes from another Receiver. I was facinated by all the amazing things the tapes talked about, and found the more meta tapes especially entertaining. They are also very effective at invoking various emotions, especially after you've collected a few tapes and the transmission is becomming less and less corrupted. The desperate struggle of you as one of the few survivors of the Mind-Kill is palpable, and the tapes gave a small feeling of hope as I searched desperately for more ammo and flashlights. The game is very good at drawing you in, and I'm so glad to see video game developers actually exploring the possibilities of their media, and not make the same games over and over again with less depth but prettier lighting.I highly recommend Receiver, and I feel as many people as possible should experience it. 10/10, would Receive again!

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Wow. I have gotten so tired of the frivolous way in which most games treat Armed/Gun warfare. COD kids running around concerned with their 360 no scopes, and silly psychopathic lemmings style behavior. This game laughs in the face of that nonsense. It is brutal, it is unforgiving, minimalist yet complex. Few games have inspired me to write a review, fewer still have ever gotten me to post one, as it usually feels like too much hassle, but this game...I wrote a review after only playing it for a relatively short while. I don't know how much replayability most will find in it, but for the price and the intention of expansion, I say throw caution to the wind and learn something for once. If you don't know basic gun operation...in real life, after this you should have a pretty good idea. In my opinion, if for experience alone, this game is worth it. If you think you are some gun toting ace, give this a whirl and see what your made of. This review is written by a real gun owner. I personally appreciated the simulation quality of the gun mechanics. Rating: A+/(9.5/10)/(4.75/5)

												Not really a game, more of an experiment in techniques on how to handle firearm mechanics in video games. Your goal is to collect all eleven casette tapes in each playthrough. The world is randomly generated each time, with enemies, ammunition, and casette tapes never in the same place as last time.Although slow paced it can get pretty intense at times. For example I was running from one the flying enemies whilst inserting bullets into an empty magazine, inserting the magazine in the gun, pulling back the slide, and cocking the hammer. All done manually.Lastly it has some optimization issues, despite the fact that it's a pretty hideous game to look at on a technical level.Firearm aficionados will get a kick out of it, but if you're not an avid fan of guns I'd stay away.There are mods available that add new weapons such as the Thompson M1A1 and the beautiful C96!

Posted: March 5, 2014
												Receiver is a rather simple (on the surface) FPS game. Receiver's main objective is to find cassette tapes that tell a story of the society and troubles of the world, as well as how to operate a firearm. The gunplay is fantastic, for it focuses on semi-realism. Destroy the kill-bots with precise firing by hitting key parts such as the cameras, engine, battery, or (in the case of the flying taser-bots) the rotor. After the threat is neutralized, you should check your ammol without having a silly HUD, the game forces/allows you to pull the magazine from your gun (or open slide out the cylinder) to check how much ammo you have left. Maybe you emptied the clip and recently reloaded your gun, but you're not sure you got one in the chamber. Simply pull the slide back halfway, and take a peek! Overall, Receiver is easily worth the sale price of $5, and definitely more, although the price helps in the fun. 10/10

Posted: July 17, 2013
												　このゲームを要約すると、「ガンオタが銃の構造をリアルに作ったけど、他にまで手が回らなかった」　マガジンに弾をひとつひとつ込め、銃に装填しスライドロックを解除する……リロード一つするのにも大変なゲーム。リアルを追求しまくったお陰で、使うのか使わないのかよく解らないセーフティロックまであったりしちゃいます。　Ｒキーを押すと、スライドを動かして弾が飛び出るのでＲ＝リロードの人は注意ですｗだけど、銃をリアルに使うとこういう感じだよね、と、いう雰囲気は味わえるかもしれません。　２時間程プレイしてみましたが、コルト1911っぽい銃、リボルバー、グロックのピストルマシンガン、フラッシュライトがランダム初期装備で、弾薬数、マガジン数などランダム。途中途中に弾薬が落ちていることもあれば全然見付からないこともあったり……。しかも、暗い所から始まり、フラッシュライトが無い状態からだと、画面が真っ暗というより真っ黒でどこへいけばいいのか全くわかりません。と、いうか目的がよく解らないです。敵は、タレットが至る所に設置されていたり、空中浮遊しているスタンガンのような機械がいて、見つかると戦闘になりますが、倒すのが非常に大変。マップも同じようなところなので迷います。果たしてサブマシンガンやライフルはこの先出るのだろうか……いや、出ないだろうね。　そんな感じのゲームです。

Posted: April 22, 2014
												A great concept, but the setting and goals aren't to my liking.The mechanics do a great job of rethinking a concept that is often glossed over in other games (reloading), but it's really the only thing that carries the game.I'd give it a go if you're into game design in any way, but otherwise there's not much here.

Posted: April 23, 2014
												Receiver's fun. You run around shooting these sneaky little robots. The twist is that the gun that you weild is painfully realistic. Quite a few firearm mechanics come into play in this game. For someone like me who has shot guns quite a bit(FAR from an expert with guns though), I picked up on it pretty quick. For someone with less knowledge about firearms, these mechanics may take awhile to learn and might be frustrating. But that's the game really. It's less about the robots and more about you maneuvering this machine you're shooting them with. You have to remember all the steps of reloading in order and have to be able to do it fast. The game looks nice. It's going for a minimalistic style which it achieves nicely(at least to my eyes).However, it's HORRIBLY optimized. You've probably heard this from the bad reviews, and what they say is true. For how it looks and how much is going on, this game should not run my graphics card hotter than Battlefeild at a lower frame rate. As long as you have a decent system that can run this, you'll be fine, but it's still rediculous none the less. There's also problems with the map spawning to. I sometimes find myself getting stuck in certain areas and have to restart because there's no place to go. With all it's problems, it's still amazingly fun. Don't let all of this deter you. If you have $5, go for it. It's a few hours entertainment for less than the cost of a movie ticket.

Posted: April 23, 2014
												The good -Realistic gun mechanics that show how simplified guns really are in most video games -Pseudo-random world generation makes for a different game every time -Extremely intense gameplay, due to permadeath -Enemy drones malfunction based on where you shoot them. (example, shoot the battery and the drone stops rotating, or shoot the tazer and a drone will follow you around but can't hurt you) This can make for some interesting situations. -Overall an extremely challengeing game, still haven't gotten more then 5 tapes. The bad -Very poorly optimized. My computer gets pretty hot. -Quite a few bugs, my flashlight never works anymore, some stairs you cant climb without jumping. -Visually unappealing, simple shapes and no texturing.  -Despite random level generation, the game doesn't have much replayability. You'll probably see all the rooms within half an hour.  -Only two different types of enemies.  -Sometimes you will respawn with little to no ammo, and have to die and restart.Some general opinions If you are looking for any of these types of games you shouldn't buy receiver. -You are looking for a game with replayability -You are looking for a game with decent graphics. -You are looking for a cakewalk of a game (easy).If you can get over these things then I say go for it. Me personally though, I kinda wish I had my $5 back (but now that I have it I'll try to beat it).

												This game made simple gun play incredibly fun and once you master the controls it feels amazing to be able to pull off a reload under pressure. Due the RNG nature of the game the win condition item, cassettes, can drop with wildly varying frequencies but oddly enough with little variation within one run. If you spawn in a room with a cassette or two already there chances are high that you’ll have a third or fourth within a few minutes while spawning in an empty room can leave you wandering with 10 or more minutes between cassettes. That being said the story is horrifying and even though collecting the cassettes is the game objective it doesn't even come close to justifying a purchase. Posted: March 3, 2014
												Not even for a dollar.Look this game is an awesome concept and the realistic gun mechanics are an amazing perspective compared to the usual spray then reload games.  It also has some pretty neat sounding music.  However, it was made unbelievably quickly within just a few days for a game competition so it lacks a lot of finer details.I find it really awesome that you operate the gun in a very realistic way and must be aware of the mechanisms at all times to know how many bullets you have left, if safety is off or on, and basically if it's gonna fire or not. That's about all the good though, as this game is very limited elsewhere.  The story line is poorly thought out and not carried out very well.  All you do is collect tapes much like paper pages in a Slender game.  The only enemy you have are robots, that's it.  They are very challenging, but quickly get boring after 10 or so of them.  Other than the realistic gun mechanics, the game has nothing else in it.  The textures are plain, the graphics only semi-decent for the low resolution of the models, and there is little more entertainment than just firing off rounds all over randomly.  The thing that makes me most upset is how the developer has dropped this game like a bad habit.  There have been no updates or known plans for better development.  Given some time, better textures could be added, more enemies could be put in, there could be more mechanics (such as physics), and definitely way more guns than just a semi-automatic pistol and a revolver.  If they added to the game and actually developed it further...maybe I'd change my mind.

Posted: July 26, 2013
												Receiver is an amazing proof-of-concept. The guns are more realistic, and take more knowledge to handle than just "press R to reload". Having to manually insert each bullet into the magazine (and remember to manually chamber the first round) makes each gun feel like a tool, like something more solid and tangible. That builds a strong connection between you and your gun, making the shooting more exciting. I would love to see the ideas of Receiver used in a mainstream game. Would love to.That said, Receiver itself is a fun distraction, but not much of a "game". After a half hour you'll likely feel you've seen everything worth seeing, and not be wrong. It's worth buying to experience what FPS games could do, as that proof-of-concept, and support the developers.

Posted: February 5, 2015
												First impressions (that will probably get drowned out in the sea of review and the fact that they are at the bottom of the steam store page.)Reciever is delightfully complex and a welcome challenge and change for any venterned fps player.The game however is very much a "very early alpha"/prototype, but with a lot of future potential.By focusing on realistic detail of gun usage, the challenge no longer becomes about snap reaction times with pointing and clicking, but rather the challenge comes from profecient weapon use against the simplest of enemies.My first few rounds I heavily relied on using the help menu to guide me through the complex key presses needed to opertate my random firearm. I quickly took up the challenge to learn the keys and the appropritae sequences without relying on the guide, I dare say this only took me 20 minutes of play time to get down pat.Despite the simplistic nature of the enemies (a drone that has to ram you and has terrible flight pathing, and a stationary turret that scans in a radial loop) Their loud 'target accquired' beeps caused overwhelmingly tense situations unrivalled by any other modern FPS. These situations were only exacerbated by knowing it was one hit one kill from these drones, forcing you to be swift and always ready.As I summarised, the game is very earlier in development. Hopefully development continues and more content is added at a frequent pace.$5 dollars is I think a bit much for this game in its current state, but liek most early access games, its a entry bar none that gets you in on the ground floor before its worth more.I'd say check it out if your interested in a truley new spin on fps!

												Receiver is a fun little FPS game which focuses on some pretty advanced and realistic gun control mechanics.You control every aspect of using whichever firearm you randomly spawn with from manually loading bullets into the magazine to removing the magazine and pulling the slide.You roam around the randomly generated map collecting bullets, flashlights and tapes which give you the insight into Receiver's background story. You win once you have collected all 11 tapes.In my opinion, the price of £4 is well worth the experience of originally trying to work out the weapon mechanics to roaming around taking out the hostile drones like a professional.There are also mods for Receiver which expand upon the original three firearms and include bug fixes and optimisations which I highly recommend.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												Receiver features the most fully simulated gun mechanics in any game I've played yet. The concept is very solid, challenging, and satisfying: operating each part of a gun individually. There is a mod that adds a Remington 870, a Thompson submachine gun, and another handgun. Each weapon type behaves and is operated differently. There is even more that can be done in simulating the weapons, however, and the nuances of the weapons couldn't be captured in just a week's time for development. I hope to see these complex gun mechanics in other games and I hope to see the concept developed further, perhaps in VR, where key memorization is not as needed.

Posted: January 24, 2015
												While being very simple, this game feels integral and smooth. When you get used to the routine operations, the gun feels like it's your avatar - kinda like a PC in some RPG. 4 of 10 times you die because you didn't pay attention to the gun.Two types of enemies - stationary turrets and flying melee drones - may seem scarce at first, but they feel very, very solid: sounds, damage zones (turrets can be disabled in several ways, like destroying the camera or the battery compartment, etc), camera lights and the overall feel. The complete spawn randomness makes you constantly feel on edge: 5 out of 10 times you die because you haven't encountered enemies for a while, got lulled into carelessness and strolled around the corner without a care in the world.This and the need to constantly be aware of your gun's condition and the number of remaining bullets provokes you to actually think and plan your encounters (however lame that may sound in this case).The one unpleasant thing I can't come to terms with is the inability to drop flashlights. Once I got lucky and found 6! of them, so that my inventory actually continued off-screen. And you can't really avoid picking them as they usually spawn in the middle of a pile of bullets.Now I wish the modern shooters had an option to turn on gun handling, the immersion could be tremendous; but undoubtedly big title developers won't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥ So sad :(.

Posted: December 9, 2014
												This game is more a less a rogue-like tech demo. The price and the videos about it should reflect that to players.The premise of the game is that players will start off with a pistol, it could be a revolver base or a magazine based pistol.  From there, you are going around looking for recordings to find out more about the area that you are trying to escape.  Casing point though, it takes a backseat to the mechanics.One of the core concepts of this "demo" is that it is fairly thrilling to reload a pistol all the way through by manipulating each of its mechanisms in a fluid manner under pressure. The hammer, the chamber, the loading or unloading of the magazine all have dedicated buttons which gives this demo a big learning curve because it's not as simple as press "R" to reload your magazines anymore.The revolvers are simpler and take less time to learn to reload and ready for firing.As for the other parts of the game, the elements of the environment and the mechanical enemies are simple polygons.  It gets the job done.

Posted: March 19
												This game is by far the most interesting games I've come to know, and heres a few reasons why:1. Mechanics. The weapon mechanics in Receiver are some of the most complex, frustrating and hair-pull-inducing I've ever seen, and thats why they're so good. This game forces you to adapt to how it must be played and gives no way around that. 2. Unfairness. One shot and you're dead. Thats it. You have 2 options: FIght or Flight. I've found myself accidently shooting at the ground and end up killing myself from MY OWN SHOT.3. Story. While not fully explained from the get-go, it is more or less pieced together through the 11 tapes you find. The games lore must be discovered, not given away in the tutorial.4. Lack Of Tutorial. This is what makes Receiver very interesting. The player is not given hints, directions, instructions, or anything of the like. The game gives the player a gun, a flashlight (sometimes), a clip or two and some bullets, then essentially pats the player on the back, smiles and says "Good luck."5. Damage. When you land a shot on an enemy, there's a chance that bullet has affected them and, hopefully, crippled them in a way. A shot to the turrets gun or the drones tazer disarms them. A shot to the camera and they are blind. A shot to the battery pack and they go down. Every shot counts, so aim wisely.If you have 5$ and some spare sanity you've been itching to lose, pick up Receiver and give it a run.

Posted: June 27, 2013
												So I pre-ordered Overgrowth (which looks like it's going to be awesome) to get the alpha, and Wolfire games surprised me by giving me a free steam code for this with the pre-order. I knew the Overgrowth download would take a while, so I put in the code, downloaded the game, and played it to pass the time. I probably spent about an hour playing this in that one sitting. As simple as the game is, it keeps the game alive by making sure you never play the same way twice. You always spawn with a random gun, in random conditons, with random magazines with random amounts of ammo, in a random place, on a randomly generated map. And nothing is as satisfying as releasing the slide on a freshly reloaded mag and knowing you just did that from memory.  Definitely worth pre-ordering Overgrowth or $5, plus at least an hour of your life addicted to it.

Posted: November 29, 2015
												This game is really, really good if you're looking for a edge-of-your-seat shooter, although I hesitate to call it a shooter, because it brings so much more to the table. It's a mix of stealth, exploration, and plain FPS with a very important twist. No action is automatic with your gun; if you want to reload, you have to drop the magazine, put it in your inventory, pull out another magazine, put it in your gun, and♥♥♥♥♥♥it. This mechanic really helps with the immersion in an already deeply atmospheric game. Pros: -Realistic gun control-Amazing depth of play with three guns and two enemies-Interesting plot, if you can collect the tapes to reveal it -All-around funCons:-Somewhat buggy at times-Doesn't run on lower-mid range computers (speaking from when I was playing on a Macbook Pro, not sure if it's been optimised since)Even if you're not a fan of FPS's, I recommend this game just for the plot and atmosphere, and for 5 bucks (2 right now!), it's really a steal.9/10 overall

Posted: December 8, 2015
												This... Isn't really a game.TL;DR at the bottomReceiver is a one mode 'game' in which you spawn randomly in a generated 3D world with no textures, with one of three guns, a random amount of ammo, and sometimes a flashlight. Your goal is like slender or other random generated indie games, which is to collect all the messages throughout the level which include voice overs that vaguely describe some plot to give the game some kind of flavor or depth, and in my opinion fails to do so. Collecting all of them means you win, or, at least that's what I'm told, the game didn't keep my attention enough to complete a run through.Part of the reason for that is this game is rediculously unforgiving. There are only two annoying enemies in this game. Flying buzzsaw robots from Half Life 2 and shooting turrets from Portal. They both kill you in one hit, but the same isn't true for you. Many times you aim and shoot at them and for some reason their 'weak point' hitbox doesn't register. It is overall very frustrating, especially if you can't find a flashlight and you happen to be surrounded by very dark rooms. I ended up just cranking up my gamma.One last deal breakingly bad thing in this game. When you enter a new generated area (which there are like 6 or so for the game to load to my knowledge), the game freezes for a split second. My computer more than exceeds the requirments this game suggests, but it happens every other time, and can mean a turret might shoot me when it otherwise would not, which, again, means a complete game over and starting the ENTIRE game from scratch.The redeeming factor of this game is the neat gun concept. You are given no tutorial, but instead a key map shows up on the right of the screen with the next step to getting the gun ready to fire highlighted. A different button is required to perform all of the functions of the pistol you spawn with, from safety, to releasing the slide, to loading an empty mag with fresh rounds. Speeding up this process by remembering the right combination of presses is pretty rewarding, and is also very accurate to real life and educational to those that don't really know how guns work. Slow claps.If this pistol simulator wants to keep marketing itself as a game it needs a MAJOR content update. New enemies, objectives, a difficulty other than butt clenchingly hard, and a story that isn't one guy breathing into a mic.TL;DR- Only 3 guns, 2 enemies, 1 game mode- Stutters at loading intervals, which can end up killing you- Has very dark areas but may or may not give you a flashlight nearby- Bland blank textures and one (maybe two?) drab songs constantly playing- Frustrating level of difficulty with no way to change it- Boring generated map- Sprinting requires spamming the W key. Seriously, when was this ever a good idea?+ Fantastic gun mechanics+ Shows promise if content keeps getting addedVerdict: Buy it on sale if you reeeeaaally want to try. But otherwise in it's current state it should be free and in beta.
